reviewText:
Okay, after playing the game for an hour, I wrote a sensible review of the game, stating I would not recommend it.
The followling is myy reveiw after 5 whole hours of existing as a miserable soldier in this war.


I likened it being repeatedly kicked in the nuts and then coaxed into giving it another go. The first reveiw was more detailed than that, but that's the gist. I pointed out some sound flaws, and held up the graphics and stability of the engine and server. I basically said it was not my cup of tea. 6 out of 8 people found my review helpful, either saying “Hey, I love games that repeatedly kick me in the balls!” and others who say “Oh, That sounds like a waste of my time and energy.” Either way- helpful.

The 2 people who did not find my review helpful took it upon themselves to say I was being to harsh, and also said I “Couldn’t review the game after only 1 hour.” I did. He was clearly in denial! But I downloaded the game AGAIN, just to be sure.

After 5 hours, I can say, I would not recommend this game to a friend. I just don’t think its fun! How’s that!

Vehicles- they are okay. The controls are messed up on the aircraft though. WAY off weirder than anything I’ve ever played were you fly a plane. But hey, I’ve never piloted an aircraft, what do I know? I know this wasn’t fun.

Character models- They are okay. You can customize them with certificates (or something) you earn or money you pay. Pretty cool. Also hard to tell people apart in various kinds of light. It’s not so clear cut as red dudes shooting blue dudes, when only small elements on a person’s suit are colored so, and the lighting is a hazy beautiful sunset PURPLE. The high tech futuristic  HUD doesn’t know if a guy is friend or foe until its too late. Maybe you can buy an upgrade for that . . . I don’t care.

Controls- they are okay. They are what I would expect. I like 3rd person with cover mechanics better, personally. I say 1st Person Shooter and honestly, you know most of the controls. Nothing special, It gets it done.

Landscape- You are on a planet with some continents divided up into a bunch of hexagons. There isn’t much in the way or realistic geological terrain, overall (like you see in Arma and DayZ- beautiful and realistic). It is more of that sculpty lumpy mountain looking stuff, and here are some really big rocks, trees, a swamp, like that. Some places are better than others. It’s not bad, it’s just nothing special. There is a base every 100 meters or so, no infrastructure, no towns, no cities, no villages, no civilians, no factories, no mines, no wildlife, no nothing. This is a planet full of military bases and there are three factions of really stupid people fighting over it FOR WHAT!?!?   Honestly, I don’t care. I didn’t see anything worth fighting for. That brings us to . . . .

Story- The planet should be a desolate wasteland of craters and corpses. Or maybe one of the factions would have just nuked the whole place from orbit? Basically these three armies are fighting each other with guns and vehicles when they have these machines that just SPEW soldiers into the fight. Put them in vehicles or squads, or drop them unrealistically from low orbit. They run about and die, only to be spewed back out of the machines and given weapons and pointed in the direction of “enemy” like suicidal lemmings!  Why? There are evil republicans, of course, high tech homosexuals, why not, and super awesome rebellious Rock-and-Roll rebels! I don't know what they are fighting for.

The Action- The most fun I had was repairing stuff. I followed some tanks around and repaired them, used their guns until they needed repairs, repaired them. Me and a billion others took a giant mushroom place. Cool. I repaired some guns and shot at tanks and repaired some AA guns and shot at aircraft. Cool. I climbed a mountain and got shot in the face. Disappointing. Most of it is spawn, turn a corner die, spawn run a half mile, die, spawn, grenade, die, spawn, fall, die, spawn, try to repair some shield generator, get shot in the face, die.

Wrap up- This is the longest review I have written. I honestly, just don’t really like wild disorganized hari-kari PVP. This is not a team assaulting a fortified position . . . It is three armies ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at each other as hard as they can, and whoever is standing on the pile at the end . . . wins?
After 30 minutes, I knew it wasn’t my thing. After 5 hours, I feel cheated. I can’t get that time back and I gained nothing as a human. I already know we are insignificant and conflict is ultimately pointless. This game offers me nothing I can’t have somewhere else and have more fun. Does that mean you will not like it? By all means, use that free will, you may love it. I have met plenty of people into S&M. Would I recommend it to a friend? I did, because misery loves company, but I regret it. It was wrong of me in my subjective view of morality as it stands now. I hope he will forgive me one day. NO, I will not recommend this game to a friend. If they ask, I’ll just say “Nah, that’s not my cup of tea.”

Is there anything they could do to change it and make it more palatable to me? No, and I don’t think they should. The game has an audience that loves it. Let it be.

Uninstalls like a champ, even the second time around.

reviewText:
I should quantify everything that follows by first saying I was a HUGE fan of Planetside 1 (yeah...I have my CR5 VS Rexo as my profile picture on Steam).

I've just not been able to get in to PS2 at all however.  The primary reason for this would likely be because it plays nothing like the first game - it retains the same kind of scope, but for the most part the core mechanics are completely different.

I realise now I was hoping for a graphically-updated clone of PS1, and while I accept that wouldn't exactly constitute 'progress', I'm not convinced that the design decisions made here push the game on in any great leaps and bounds.  As an example, it's worth comparing the inventory or loadout system of the two games.  In PS1, players built their own loadouts from the ground up with overall carrying capacity dictated by the type of armour worn.  The weapons and equipment available were restricted by the branches of the various combat disciplines that had been unlocked - using points gained by levelling one's character.  This approach allowed for HUGE variation between loadouts for individual characters and meant that genuine mulit-tasking was possible.  By contrast, PS2 has a much more rigid and defined class system which will be more familiar to players of 'traditional' shooters and is arguably less daunting to get to grips with - if ultimately more generic and unsatisfying.

Less tangible - but equally off-putting, for me at least - is the feel of the battles.  PS1 often had very clearly defined battle lines and it was possible to sense and react to the ebb and flow of battle.  I don't get this in PS2 at all.  Large outdoor fights give the impression of many self-contained deathmatches all going on at once and seem utterly disorganised.  Is this a result of the pacing of the game?  Possibly.  I believe the TTK may be generally lower than it was in the original and this coupled with the faster character movement undeniably makes the game a very diffeerent proposition to the first.

I'm quite sure than in its own right, the fare on offer is enjoyable to many - just don't expect anything like the slow(ish) pace of the first game and the almost 'trench warfare' scenarios that could develop.

Overall, I really wanted to like this game but the sad truth for me is that it's lost too much of what made the original so special.

4/10

reviewText:
There are two ways to look at Planet Side 2.  First, you can look at it on its own, and then you can compare it to Planet Side 1.  If you are new to Planet Side, you can ignore this review, as it is an average game for most, but as the follow up to the stellar Planet Side 1, it falls flat.

PS1 was a constant battle to take over land from other teams, but what really set it apart was its pacing.  Sure, you could get tied up in a massive battle, but you could also wander off to a quiet (but not abandoned) continent and earn some points by gathering NAT.  In PS2, there are no non-combat activities, much less ones that earn you EXP and help your team.

PS1, taking part in battle was an immerse experience.  Players never magically appeared out of nowhere, they actually opened doors and hatches, and climbed in and out of vehicles.  PS2 takes a step backwards by switching to the Battlefield-like instant teleportation.  This is a huge oversight.  How would the game feel if you teleported through all doors?  Why stop at vehicles?  Hell, why even have reloading animations?  Nothing shatters one's suspension of disbelief quite like seeing matter quantum teleport en mass right before your eyes.

Planet Side 2 also removes your home continent, a in-game place you could retreat to, recover and organize a huge raid in.  Nothing can compare to the shear cool-factor of (visibly) climbing into a Galaxy transport, only to join a swarm of others, all marshaling for the invasion of a continent.  Now you just spawn in on the front line and magic-craft your vehicle.  Yet another failure.  In PS1, vehicles actually appeared to be coming from an automated factory, not just poofing into existence because 'nano machines?  Yeah! NANOMACHINES!'

PS2 is a great looking game, but the rest of its content consists of Call of Duty like compromises in the name of instant satisfaction.  These developers think we are idiots, all demanding fewer milliseconds before we can get our first kill.  It is more likely that the impatient ones scream far louder than the rest of us who enjoy a varied and nuanced experience.  Not only will I not die if every second of my time isn't spent killing or being killed, I'll actually enjoy how glorious combat is when it is punctuated amongst quieter moments.

To put another way, PS1 was like Saving Private Ryan, insane action, but with meaning and finesse giving it purpose.  Planet Side 2, like so many other games these days, is a Michael Bay movie with the human moments cut out, nothing but a non stop explosion-fest without relent or purpose.

Highly disappointing.

reviewText:
I've played this game since launch ( I haven't used the steam client for it since 2013 ) and it is still one of the marvels of Massively Multiplayer gaming. This game presents combat on a scale unrivaled by any current title out on the market, and it's done this for 3 and a half years. There is no other game out right now that can simulate the strategic importance of manpower allocation, while simultaneously providing a great shooter experience. You can kiss your 5v5, 8v8, 12v12, 24v24, and 48v48 shooters goodbye because when it comes to sheer size the 450v450v450 over the 64 square kilometer maps of Planetside blow all these games out of the water, not to mention that the game also has a player base construction system as of a week ago, turning this game into the Massively Multiplayer version of a love child between CnC Renegade and the Battlefield franchise.

All praise aside the game still has issues, the new player experience is awful, the tutorial sucks, mostly because it no longer exists, and the game will not hold your hand beyond a short message each time you encounter a new aspect of the game. Due to the game's sheer size the game is riddled with bugs, thankfully the majority of the major ones have been fixed in the time since launch, but there are still a few stinkers here and there. The game game map's massive size also means that on off peak hours finding a fight can be difficult, but still possible on if you look hard enough.

So, do I recommend this game? Yes, if you are willing to endure the gauntlet of skill curve of Dark Souls and the level of tutorial of Dwarf Fortress. This game can easily be the best you've ever played, if you take the time to learn it.

Here's a few tips for new players:

Don't be discouraged by dying a lot, lots of people in a fight means you will get shot from everywhere. (Including your teammates if you aren't careful)

Start by playing a support class, (Medic and Engineer) this will allow you to contribute to the team without worrying about getting a ton of kills, and will help you learn how the battles flow so you can understand how to play the combat classes more effectively.

Join a squad! The game is an MMO, which means playing with other people is the mainstay of the game, good squad leaders will help you learn the game as well as find, or make good, fun, fights for the squad to participate in.

Commit at least 10 hours to the game before you decide to put it down. I know a lot of people think the game should sell itself in the first 30 min of gameplay, but this game almost never does, and if you put it down before you see the depth of the game you will have deprived yourself of one of the best Multiplayer experiences in the industry.

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nYou'll hear a lot of complaints about this game: that it's not very newbie friendly, that it's full of casuals, that there are a lot of things to learn, that the shooting is difficult due a combination of recoil and long time to kill, that it feels pointless due to a lack of story and reards, that it's demanding on hardware, and that the graphics aren't anything special. All these complaints are, to some greater or lesser extent, true, but I still love this game. The scale is like nothing else I've ever seen: this is a pure PvP shooter where the server is an entire planet with thousands of players rather than a single battlefield with a few dozen players at most. Infantry, ground vehicle, and air vehicle combat are all seamlessly integrated with one another. It's free, and it's perfectly viable and enjoyable to play without ever paying a cent. It has a broad and very helpful internet subculture around it. There are three different factions to choose from, alike enough that skills learned in one faction will be useful in another but different enough that there are clear pros and cons to each. I recommend everyone give this game a chance. It's free, it does a lot of things well, and there is nothing else like it.

reviewText:
The game certainly delivers on it's promise, but at the same time, it's promise is exactly what causes problems depending on the type of fun you are looking for.

Yes, it is invigorating to see such a massive world layed out where battles can be happening between hundreds of people across different fronts. At the same time, hundreds of people battling in clusters of anywhere from 10 to 100 on a side means that as an individual soldier, your presence matters far less that in other shooters. Killing one to several enemies almost inevitably reveals your position to other enemies who will rapidly end your life, driving a tank across the field results in all enemy tanks and anti tank gunners to quickly end your life.

There is no room in this game for solo or lone wolf style play beyond perhaps sniping in a support role. As a team game however, the game does work quite well.

Ultimately, the downfall of the game is that every point of conflict ultimately boils down to a very simple formula of attacking and defending capture points. The dynamic aspect is centered around where mobile spawns are placed and how many people happen to be on the attacking or defending side.

Now I admit, I do not have many hours invested in the game on steam but at this point, I dont feel much more time is needed to understand that this is essentially battlefield without the destructible environments and a larger player pool. Try it if you are curious but the repetive nature of combat combined with the slow pace of the game reminded me far too much of Halo.

reviewText:
Planetside 2 might seem like an amazing game at the start, but as you keep playing more and more, you'll notice the high amount of problems this game has and how bad it is.

In Planetside 2 you have three factions, the oppressive and communist like Terran Republic, the freedom fighting New Conglomerate and the Technology worshiping Vanu Sovereignty.
Each side has different weapons, one different air vehicle and one different main battle tank, rest of the vehicles are common pool shared vehicles.

Terran Republic is known for it's fast fire rate, low recoil first shot multipliers and large amounts of ammo per magazine however their weapons are a bit harder to control during medium to long range fights because of their higher fire rates.
The Terran Republic's main battle tank is the prowler, it's equipped with a dual cannon, making it the best main battle tank for anti infantry combat, it is also the fastest tank in the game and is able to anchor it self onto the ground to fire faster,reload faster and make it's explosive shells fly faster.
The Terran Republic's empire specific fighter, the mosquito is the fastest fighter in the game, has the fastest fire rate and the highest ammo count but the lowest damage

New Conglomerate is known for being the hardest hitting faction, they have the highest damage weapons but tend to have the lowest amount of ammo and slowest fire rates, their weapons have higher recoil and the fastest bullet velocity in the game.
The New Conglomerate main battle tank is the Vanguard, it is the slowest moving tank in the game but it does the highest amount of damage, has the fastest velocity on it's main cannon and can take far more abuse than any other tank, it also is able to activate a short invulnerability shield which is at the moment  pretty overpowered , it allows the tank to easily turn a lost situation into an instant win during close range tank fights.
The New Conglomerate's empire specific fighter, the Reaver is the hardest hitting fighter in the game but has the slowest fire rate and lowest ammo count in it's weapons.

Vanu Sovereignty is know for being a very adaptive empire, they don't have high fire rates like the TR or the high damage like the NC but instead their weapons are sorta in-between the stats you'd see on a TR and NC gun, they're pretty much jacks of all trades but masters of none sadly.
The Vanu Sovereignty's main battle tank, the Magrider is a hover tank, it has the lowest damage per second(DPS) and slowest velocity but it is the most accurate tank and is able to strafe and climb large mountains and buildings which the other tanks cannot do, it's a tank that's made for dodging incoming enemy projectiles and flanking the enemy quickly.
The Vanu Sovereignty's empire specific fighter, the Scythe is the most accurate fighter in the game, it has the fastest velocity and the best air brakes however it is the slowest fighter in the game and does not have the higher fire rate of the Mosquito or the high damage of the Reaver instead it's damage and fire rate is between that of a Mosquito and Reaver.

Now that i've introduced you to the three factions, I'll just quickly describe what the objective is in Planetside 2.
In Planetside 2 you have to captures bases for your empire, the more bases you have the closer you get to locking down a continent for your empire which gives you a50% discount for equipment/vehicle/aircraft.During the day you'll have random Alerts which pop up giving everyone the same objectives like capture X amount of Y or hold the most territory on a continent before the timer runs out. The victors get awarded with more XP and bragging rights for the win.
In Planetside 2 you can have up to 2000 players on a single continent, ATM there's 4 continents in the game so a server can have up to 8000 people fighting each other, in the future when they add more continents they'll keep increasing the maximum player cap each time by 2000.
Battles in Planetside 2 are pretty spectacular, huge tanks fights in large open fields, multiple large ships flying up in the air doing dog fights, organized outfits(Clans) working together trying to capture territory for their empire it's amazing when you see it all in motion, there's simply no other FPS Multiplayer game that can do this at the moment.

Now that I'm done explaining the basics to the people who are new or are planing to download the game, it's time to share the large amount of problems the game has, let's begin :
1 : For a game that's supposedly all about working together as  a team to win, people tend to play the game as more of a large endless Team Deathmatch, only trying to get more kills and higher KDr so they can get higher levels and get more medals.
Yes, this is an issue with the playerbase however the reason this happens is because the game is lacking a reason for you to capture territory and win things for your empire, you get far more awarded if you go to a fight where you can easily get some nice kills than going to a fight where you're outnumbered and trying to defend a base that's required to win an alert.
There's a large lack of a metagame and an endgame in Planetside 2, if an empire captures a continent nothing special happens, that empire only gets a 50% discount for vehicles or equipment for a short time which makes capturing continents pretty pointless.
So after a few weeks you'll realize there's no point in Planetside 2 except to get more weapons,medals and improve your stats which is really,really sad.
The game badly needs a good metagame and endgame so Planetside 2 can finally become that nice teamwork large scale game about fighting for your empire with your friends.

2:The game has serious issues with bugs,low frame rate and constant crashes. The game just loves to crash on a occasion, the frame rate can hit such low levels the game turns into a power point presentation even on a above average PC,the game is infested with bugs where your vehicles might randomly explode because you touched some rock at a bad angle or you're unable to access the map to respawn forcing you to end the game with the task manager and the list goes on.

3:The game reuses a lot of assets on different weapons, ALOT of guns in the game looks exactly the same and some even sound the same, they badly need to update these models so you can actually tell apart which gun is which without having to check a damn description.

4:The game has serious issues with lag and hitbox detection, hitboxes in Planetside 2 sometimes just stop working, you might find yourself unloading all your ammo into someone at point blank range just to find out you did 0 damage to him and you'll die a fair amount while behind cover or going around corners since the game has some issues with lag compensation.
This happens very often nowadays to the point where i can hardly play the game anymore, some of the worst dedicated servers iv'e ever seen in a video game.

5: The game has a lot of problems with bug exploiters and hackers, the game has a sewere lack of Game Masters to keep servers in check from hackers and people who bug exploit like clipping thru a floor and killing everyone on a capture point inside a base or a hacker who flies around in a tank or as infantry and headshots you immediately if he notices you and than just teleports somewhere else, Planetside 2 needs to have it's anti-cheat improved and more game masters for each server to keep things in check so these type of people don't ruin the game for everyone.

Bottom line, Planetside 2 will make you regret the day you decided to play it.
Broken servers with extreme high pings, a hit detection that works only half of the time, a toxic,unfriendly and bad player base that turns newcomers into more toxic ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that keep destroying the community, developers that fail to accomplish anything, lead directors that continuously lie to it's players and so many more things which i sadly can't fit here.

In this far flung retrofuturistic neotopian post-progressive CRPG, you play as the egregious neuromancer Cornelius Holliday.

On the run from the Globotech megacorporation for cyber crimes you never committed, you must rely on stealth and espionage to overcome obstacles, various cybertronic enemies, and discover the reason behind the lies, and ultimately the truth about yourself.

This masterpiece of a game features a host of dazzlingly well-written characters, from the moody but noble extranet spacer Dax, to the sardonic, effervescent, and beautiful sprawl-urchin Vera, and many many more.

The deliberately paced and suspensful storyline is one of the best to come out of a game since 2127's VRG, 'Dark Echoes'.

Planetside 2 is a game that will be hailed for many nanocycles to come.

First, it's the type of game where you have to either play a really long time to get anything good to use, or you can pay $$ to unlock early(which is what almost everyone does.) This product does keep you on edge though, because you never know when it will freeze or CRASH AND BURN!!!!\n\nWhile there are numerous problems, there are pros to this game. reviewText:
Hi everybody. Thanks for taking time to read my review.

Planetside 2. It's free. It's fun. If you haven't downloaded it, but you're wondering if you should, read on.

3 worlds/continents and 3 armies, each with it's own special brand of technology and ideology. The gameplay is most often fast and frenetic if you're looking for action. You can join a squad and work as a team, or run independently as a loose-cannon type maverick. Or you can look at the map for where the action is and just dive in to the chaos. Alternatively, you can find a spot where you'd like to make a surprise attack and just go for it.  The important thing here is to find out what style of play suits you best and how to maximize your potential in harmony with that. In other words, play to your strengths. Figure out the faction, class, and weaponry combination that works best for you, and then attempt to play in such a way as to take advantage of your strengths and minimize your losses from blind spots and weaknesses.

The Good:

Choice. You play the way you want, whenever, however, whatever that means. You play for as long as you want, wherever you want, however you want, and then switch it up at the whim or needs of the moment. Vehicles a problem? Go anti-vehicle with the class and weaponry of your choosing. Need to capture a point covertly? Go stealth either as a sniper or stalker. Or if you don't like that option, go heavy and hide. Or go light and be nimble. Heavy casualties all around? Go medic. Allies in need of support? Go engineer and drop ammo or heal vehicles and Max suits. Want to be at the forefront of an assault? Grab a vehicle and deploy a remote base for spawning. Want to be a leader? Devote resources to opening those skills. No matter where you go and what you do, the scenery can, at times, really impress itself on your senses. The music isn't bad either, and reminds me vaguely of the Firefly show. And, if you play a lot, you can earn certs which will help you improve your skills and gear. And if you're really clever and persitent, you can do well at this game without spending tons of money.

The Bad:

Well, your starting gear is not great. You may get discouraged from getting stomped a lot. There are players who have obviously dropped money on the game, and a lot of it. You will need brains, skill, and persistence to succeed without spending money, although that's not necessarily a bad thing. And after playing for a time, you may agree that paying something for the fun you've had isn't bad either. However, the p2w feel of the game (pay to win) is more than just a subtle possibility. For instance, try playing one-on-one sniper to sniper in a battle with the beginning gear and see how long you last and how many targets you drop. Anyway, if you decide to stick with the game for any length of time, you're eventually going to want to spend somewhere in the neighborhood of $40-60 bucks to begin being on par with a lot of other players. And if you begin looking at vehicle improvements, well, the sky's the limit there.

The Ugly:

The only ugly I can really find in this game is the awakening realization that all of this is futile. War is ultimately pointless. Perhaps that's a good thing to teach people about war, but in the end you fight for a hill only to lose it again at the cost of many lives and much time. Boundaries are continually being redrawn, day after day. The battle moves from here to there and back again. And when a battle carries on for too long without much success, you'll find youself abandoned and staring at overwhelming forces alone when most of your allies have bailed because their morale is shattered or they simply don't have the attention span, resiliency, or persistence of a gnat (I'm looking at you, millenials). Of course, gnats get squashed all the time, so there's a time and place for everything I suppose.

Give it a try if you like beautiful FPS games with lots of freedom and choice. Even if it's a bit p2w, you'll still have fun getting stomped.


Note: Some aspects of play have improved since the game was first launched. For example, with the sunderer, you used to have to buy the ability to spawn a remote base and then equip that ability to actually use it. Now it appears as though you just have to unlock that ability. Press 'B' to deploy remote base in sunderer (or whatever key yours is bound to). Documentation/help in the game doesn't appear to be of much use. So you can expect to spend some time outside the game looking up certain things to figure them out or playing with them in game to learn by trial-and-error. Mostly, however, things are fairly common sense. Don't forget to look into customizing every little thing on your vehicles, weaponry, and gear to whatever you want them to be useful for. For example, the sniper's cloak can be either good for motionless use and sniping in between uses, or it can be configured to focus on stalking your prey--remaining invisible while moving in short distances, but at the cost of not being able to equip your sniper rifle.

Two Final Notes:

1. I almost forgot. ALSO, there's a player studio now in effect for SOE games. You make something for players to use and submit it for review. If it gets put in the store, you get a cut of all profits from the sale of that item. I think the percentage is 40% of the take. But if you have the necessary skills and don't mind conforming to their design/style guide, might be a good way to pay for your gear and get your work out there in front of the public. I'm not sure if they pay you cash or just station cash, but either way it's not bad for those who can and want to do it.

2. My advice to you, which I wish someone had told me, upgrade/improve/replace your secondary weapon since that affects all of your classes. No thanks is necessary.

reviewText:
This game is very interesting...
Imagine being put into a field of gun fire, barely capable of knowing who is shooting who. Maybe you come to realize that you are one of the guys in purple spandex, or that you are one of the Terran nut jobs, or even possibly the shot gun happy hillbillies. Coming to the realization of what team you're on now you need to figure out why every god dang time you set foot out in the open you are either shot, sniped, ran over, or just blown up.
With all the random senseless killing that feels as if it always favors you over everyone else, it's hard to understand why anyone woud play this game. And it's true, every time you step out of your giant bubble of a base you are now a walking target. Now it may seem unfair saying that you are a target ONLY by your enemy's standards. It would be far more realistic to say that you are technically a target  at all times (proof being that out of the 1000 deaths, a rounded off number of my deaths at one point, 100 of them were from my own team killing me). And yes, soak that in, there is god dang friendly fire. That means every time some guy hops in a plane, and by the way flying in this is very freaking hard, and decides to go all crazy thinking going upside down was a good idea he will come crashing down into whoever is on the ground. Now if the main explosion didn't kill you maybe the aftermath of the flaming parts will land on you, leaving you one of the many corpses on the ground. But it gets better... Because you may be thinking that if flying is that hard maybe that means the sky's will be clear most of the time. WRONG. Because for every game mechanic that feels impossible, there is some guy that for some god forsaken reason turns out to be MLG pro and literally takes control of the whole god dang sky.
So ya next point I'll bring out is that under all this random chaos there is actually a decent amount of organization. Crazy as it may seem there is actually outfits (clans/teams) that are capable of swinging the battle into their faction's favor. There has been times that I felt that my friends and I made that small decision that aloud our team to press forward, and that is one stinking good feeling. But imagine being part of a outfit that is organized and has 48+ people under command of one guy. Because this game is all about teamwork they will always trump any squad (smaller team of 2-12 people) and start to control the game. And that's exactly why if you get even slightly serious about playing this game you should consider joining an outfit, or at the least joining the open squads to be part of the giant zerg pushes.
But all in all this is a very interesting game. If you have the patience to learn the ropes I'm sure you'll come to the same realization that most people do, this is actually not just an interesting game, it's a great game. 9/10

reviewText:
Its like any other FPS game with too many people on one server. You rarely get the chance to learn how to play or to get in on the action because the enemy has supped up weapons, and your team does. So you just play support for them or act as their photographer.

The battlefield progression might aswell be arenas like other FPS games, because rarely do you see mass flanking tactics which could outscale waht you'd say in even older games like Battlefield1942. The battles themselves are usually repetive, though sometimes interesting, but never really satisfying. In addition to my game time here, which is fairly light, I did play in beta some.  There is some potential for you to get in with good, coordinated teams, but its not really a trend.

Most battles seem to turn into shooting at the enemy who hides behind their spawn room lockout doors, or turtling behind berms. Tanks are as flimsy as infantry, because weapons are more rock paper scissors than actually letting vehicles have some durability. That is to say, even though I'm in a tank, all vehicle weapons shred tanks. Forget about actually using tank tactics, because the game is balanced for shooting from range, which makes little sense.

Aircraft are fun; I have no real complaints. They take some getting used to, but thats expected.

There doesn't seem to be a lot of social potential in the form of sharing. You can let your friend hop on your beefed up turret and rack up the kills (realising how imbalanced upgrades are), and that's it. You can't lend them a weapon or distribute power to them in any other way afaik. Squad play without someone you know or who has a mic seems isolated unless you're on their turret, but then when they die you'll generally lose them again and not meet under the same circumstaces.

All in all, its an interesting idea. But its less than fantastic execution reveals why it uses a F2P model.

reviewText:
I just reinstalled and retried Planetside 2 for the first time since it came out, and I can say with unwavering certainty that it’s one of the very worst new player experiences I’ve ever had with a game.  It was mesmerizingly terrible at giving a positive first impression.

- Despite having just installed what one should reasonably assume was the latest version via Steam, the game still required a lengthy patching process from its own launcher upon startup, as well as a third party registration, without the ability to sync with my Steam account.

- The tutorial is stretched over a needlessly expansive area, and the narrator’s lines frequently bleed into and play over one another if one moves along ahead of the plodding pace it wants one to.  Needless to say, this renders any help such lines could lend incomprehensible and therefore useless, leaving one to flail about and learn through trial and error, rather than instruction, instead.

- The very first thing I experienced upon connecting to an Instant Action is getting spawn killed with an airstrike not one second after setting foot on the ground.  Fan-♥♥♥♥ing-tastic.

- The UI is one of the very worst I’ve ever encountered in terms of giving mechanical information to new players.  I know it shows information on controlled areas, flashpoints, how many friendlies and hostiles are detected in an area, etc, and that’s all nice; however, there are some much more practical questions it seems intent on not answering.  Where can I spawn?  How can I change respawn locations?  Why, when I attempt to decipher the help menu tooltips for the map, and find that I must use warp facilities to change spawn regions, am I greeted with an insta-death “restricted area” message upon attempting to reach one of those facilities?  Who knows!  I’m just constantly told to click the “Instant Action” tab, and let the game carry me off to wherever it thinks I’m needed, regardless of whether I want that region or not.

- When I attempted to ask other players in the game chat for clarification during the respawn interim of yet another spawn kill, I was greeted with the following automated message: “The dead can’t speak.”  I actually uttered an “are you ♥♥♥♥ing kidding me?” aloud in my office at this point.

I know Planetside 2 is a well-respected game, and I’m sure, once one is familiar with it, that there’s some reason for that.  This isn’t about that.  This isn’t a comprehensive review, nor is it a commentary upon the overall quality of the game. This is simply a commentary regarding the initial impression its current version gives to new, uninitiated players.  The short version is this: I felt unwelcome, not by the players, not by my squad, not by my faction, but by the game itself, as a newcomer to Planetside 2.  At every turn, it seemed as though I was getting punished for not knowing things that a proper tutorial should have taught me, for not realizing the answers to questions I didn’t realize I even needed to ask.  It felt as if it were deliberately obfuscating critical information that it just expected me to know without proper instruction.

I’ll make this as clear as I can: My initial impressions of Planetside 2 were so negative that I’ve no desire to learn the lessons necessary to further understand the game.  I’m sure the answers are there.  I’m just left with such a poor impression of my experience that I’ve no inclination to pursue them.  I’m leaving the game - again - and this time, I’m not returning.

reviewText:
Steam says I have as little as one hour playtime on this game, but in this case I have to disagree with steam. Due to the steam version only being playable in the US I had to download an EU version elsewhere. I now have at least 200 hours play time on this game. This is definitely one of the best MMOFPS games out there. There is so much to this game that it is impossible not to find something to suit you. However one downpoint to the game that put me off was that even though it is free to play, it's pay to win. At least half of your deaths will be to a player who has spent a ton of money on the best weapons ect. Now when I say that it isn't as bad as it seems as all purchasable items can be earned by free to play players but it takes a lot longer. The graphics, size and gameplay easily make up for this.

TL;DR
If you were looking for a new FPS game that is massive, provides hours of fun and is no cost to you, then look no further than Planetside 2. This game definitely deserves a thumbs-up.

reviewText:
The most epic F2P PvP shooter out there. Organized mess with about 100 guys fighting over a base, trying to capture it. 20 tanks, 10 jets and 50 armed men on foot. just wow. 3 factions, each with its own indivudal playstyle, weapons, vehicles. Some faction may have better vehicles than others but on the other hand they can lack on the force of their infantry weapons so there is always a balance and you can play faction which you like, not just which is strong. Some people may not trust F2P games, but this example of the perfect F2P game. microtransactions are not needed, shop offers comsetic items, xp and ingame currency boosters and weapons which you can all unlock with ingame currency. This game has a really neat ingame currency system- each 250 xp you gain 1 Cert point (ingame currency). This means the better you play the more money you will have.And theres a lot of opportunities to earn money- killing, assisting, spotting, damaging vehicles, airplanes, killing at longe range, objective capturing and the list goes on and on. It may be a grind but once you will learn to be most effective at the certain situation money should not be a problem.
Comunnity of this game is for me as a lone wolf player somewhat between ok and nice- you can and you will occasionally kill someone on your side, but thats not a problem, just apologise and everything is ok, most people even dont bother with it.
No frequent insults and ***holes as far in my 450 hours journey, so thats nice I think.


Pros
-Massive scale of maps, battles and continents
-Nice graphics
-3 factions with its own playstyle
-Great community
-No need to spend real money
-Sony sometimes gives away promo codes for free weapons, boosts, etc..

Cons
-The game is very greedy, so its possible that people with not so good PC wont be able to play it
-The ingame currency may have slower income for novice players
-Sometimes very time consuming as you cant afford to take a dump when there is a huge battle and every single man counts.

10/10

reviewText:
Quite simply the best simulator of an actual warzone I have yet seen. In this game... you're not the big damn hero, the nexplicably skilled protagonist veteran soldier. You are a grunt. You are just another soldier. But so is everyone else. And everyone means a BIG everyone. At your side are literally hundreds of other soldiers, all real people. Against you... yep, another few hundred. Your warzone is an epic landscape dotted with forts, mountains, canyons and outposts, each of which is constantly changing hands. Your travel includes tanks, hover tanks, planes, transport planes, and more. Your tactics are myriad, and can be done independently or in squads. Will you cloak as an infiltrator and do some forward recon (which really is useful, as unless spotted, you have no idea where your enemy is, and although not quite at real life, bullets still kill pretty fast). WIll you hold a shield line with dozens of other brother and sibling soldiers against a massed charge? Will you perform harrying attacks, leaping and jettting around as a light assault soldier to flank a larger foe before zooming back into safety? Or will you lead a spearhead of heavy armour on a stronghold, blowing apart your foes before leaping clear to clear it room by room and secure your objectives.

This is a real war. Prepare to go Planetside.

9/10.

reviewText:
one of the best f2p and fps game out there.

+++++ NOT pay to win. (grind to win but thats ok.) You won't see cheap moves like buyable classes or races.
+ Truely massive battles. HUGE maps. 100 vs 100 (and vs 100?) is a common thing.
+ The best gfx and atmosphere you can find for a f2p game.
+ 3x faction pvp system
+ ingame platoon management
+ So much fun when in an outfit (guild) , especially if your leader is able to read the map and develop strategies.
+ Start as a lame soldier and grind your way to become a Leader/ Scout/ Medic/ Anti Tank/ Pilot/ Mech/ Support/ Infiltrator/ Carrier/ What ever you really wish for.
+ Each individual is needed on the field.
+ World Events for the win.
+ Able to test eqipment before buying!
+ Active players and community.
+ It's not about mindless killing and zerg rush. Team play and right strategy are the key words.
+ new content almost every month or two. The developers really likes to develop. SOE team does good job.

----- very very poorly optimized even after all those years of development. This is the worst part of the game.
- LAG IS REAL sometimes.
- Random kids are everywhere with friendly fire.
- Solo gameplay is not rewarding and boring after a while.
- You'll have to play hundreds of hours to be able to unlock those special equipments you want.
- Competing with high lvl players is frusturating when you first start the game.
- there's a learning curve for every class, gun and vehicle in the game. Can be confusing without proper equipment.
- it takes a while to be actually usefull in the battlefield.
- some weapons are poorly balanced and very expensive (thankfully you can test them before buying)
- Air combat mechanics is not satisfying despite being so fun. It's just so hard.
- Other than world events, there are no actual quests in the game. Ghost capping is your best bet at this point
- No story or plot what so ever. (not that it needs to but still...)
- You'll have to maintain your connection for 2 hours to benefit post world event rewards or else you'll just lose 2 hours with one little disconnect.
- So much time consuming and so little rewarding sometimes. you won't believe your eyes.
- so many different enemy player skins can actually trick you as friendly. and some players are headless(?!?) somehow.
- microphone problems which they should have fixed by now.

all in all fun. A serious game for gamers with serious ambitions. Yes, I recommend this to any one interested.

reviewText:
Note this review is very strict :P .

Planetside 2 review

I USED to like the game , now I dont. I stopped playing about 3 months since March 2014 and came back during the Hossin Continent update, in hopes of a more fun and balanced gameplay. But it dissapointed me on so many levels. I was rusty when I came back but none the less I still remember the core mechanics and how to point and shoot. I played a few hours and died a lot, but its was to be expected after 3 months of leaving the game. About 15 hours in and not only my PPH (points per hour) was still drop to a measely 500/hr but my kill death ratio per game was more or less 0.2 to 0.1, not that I'm complaining since I'm an objective based player, but there is a lot of scenarios that I would have gotten a kill and survived with heavy injuries, but still alive before this update rolled out.

The changes are noticeble, infantry shield and hp was lowered , especially noticeble on the MAX suits , weapon damage was also changed for some of them. Some of the utility or special abilities of the class was changed in term of drain/ cooldown/ effect/ power , making a significant improvement in 1 of the classes but a significant drawback for the other. Graphics wise, it still looks the same but something has been change and is eating up my pc's power. Vehicles have been change as well and their weapons as well, mostly buffed. The point system is overall the same , that or slightly better. The deathcam has been improve I guess , but only slightly. The Hossin map is still under testing phase so the constant infantry and vehicles stuck are neglible and the map itself is good , thought that area lacks people playing. The teamwork of the game have mostly been lost , and objective based gameplay is pretty non-existent , most players now just care about their kill death ratio. The factions itself is now very unbalnced as well , it was about 30% TR , 30% NC , 40% VS when I last played , now its around 60% TR 30% NC and 10% VS. Now right now I maybe sound like some VS supporter, but mind you I play as all 3 factions and my favourite is TR because of their increased firerate and magazine size. But now the factions dominance is so unbalanced it's almost impossible for other minority to recover some of their bases. TR can fight on 3 front of the continent and win 2 of them, while the rest fight on the remaining continent barely making progress. As usual SOE still kept their currency at a decent price not too high and not too low. But the charge for most of the in game item is still expensive and the progress of getting cert ( the games earnable currency ) is still very bad grinding no matter how good you are.

This is what gets me now, for all games I review based on 10 main things, the New user experience, the casual player experience, the experienced player experience, music , art style (or graphics) , price ( in this case in game microtransation items ) , progress (if the game has any) , its main theme ( multiplayer , single player , story telling , etc ) , its community , and  last but not least , the MOST important thing for games, whether you are satisfied playing the game or completely hated it or mutual ( short version : fun or not).

New user (1 to 10 lvls) : Worst than before, the shield and hp system is very weak for the new user and hence they will die a lot faster and their starter weapons are not as good as they used to be.

Casual players (5 to 40 lvls) : Overall not much has changed based on what I seen , you can play normally without getting 1 shotted most of the time and an advantage will normally guarantee your 1v1 scenarios.

Experience players (41 and beyond) : Pretty much has all the infantry stuff mastered (not sure about vehicles ecause gameplay choices) , has very good gear that can overpower most low level enemy players and a very upgrade suit.

Music : Hasnt changed from what Iheard from the 3 factions, them songs is still the same I believe with TR a bit sadistic , VS and bit weird and alien like, and NC as um... western texas type of music. Weapons sounds have been change and is sounds much better now.

Graphics : No comment other than cant see cloaked inflitators while using low settings.

Price : Free but in game microtransactions are a tad bit high

Progress : Utterly slow at all levels unless you become a member, then you have a score system that actually means nothing when you think about it, cert gain is a pain as mentioned before ( exp 30 certs for a scope and 250 score pts to get 1 cert pts, so around 7500 score points to get just 1 scope) as for weapons, even longer as anyone would expect.

Main theme : It should be a competitive multiplayer on a very very very large scale. It does that well at the start but because of the unbalnced faction, its not like that anymore, you either win or lose with a landslide on the normal to large scale battles (not accounting for the 4v4 base atk and def, cuz that's not large scale :P)

Community : I chatted with the players in game, allies and enemies, visited the forums, overall quite good for a shooter, much much better than Call of Duty's community.

Fun or not: As of the Hossin update no, unless you are leveled with decent suit upgrades and weapons, new users will get destroyed no matter what, even then the unbalanced faction wars couple with slow progress makkes the game a pain to play, statistically the weapons arent overpowered when compared with the dafault ones, but when you play, you will notice that its very different in comparison. For the paid or the one with the heart  to grind throught everything, its an enjoyable experience. At the based level we all deserve a free to play game that is fun right from the start, not after paying over 60USD or grinding 800 hours into the game.

reviewText:
This game isn't a game for everyone. But it is still a game for a lot of people. For this game you sometimes need patience because not all battles are great. there is a lot of zerg-crushing and being zerg-crushed.
BUT if you find the right battle (which isn't always hard) the game shines. During afternoon, after schools are out and in the evening these awesome battles will increase because of more players on the server, and when two zerg-crushes collide there comes a battle that is just awesome to to take part in.

The game works with two currency's (not sure if i can call it a currency) called certification points (cert points) and station cash. you have to pay real money for station cash and just play for cert points.
While you can buy guns and attachments with station cash this game is (in my eyes) NOT a pay to win game. The guns and attachments can be bought with cert points too and the guns will help for sure but you still need skill and allies for victory. Upgrades for vehicles and your soldier can only be purchased with cert points.

I play the game on low graphics, but the game can look pretty good on higher settings, and the maps are quite big and well thought out. Though sometimes its hard to get to a good fight it can be very worth your time and effort to get there. There are occasional crashes I usually get like one sometimes two per session i play, but since most battle take a long time i'm back in time to still partake in the battle.

I myself love to play this game because through some of the bad things like zerg-crushing, spawn camping and crashes there is always a time a good battle arises.

reviewText:
PlanetSide 2 reminds me why I wanted to play online games in the first place: massive PvP.  This game, however, takes it to a whole new level with 3 warring factions trying to gain supreme control over 4 seperate, massive continents.  Yeah, CONTINENTS.  Not maps... freaking, giant continents.  CS:GO, Battlefield, Call of Duty simply do not compare to the scale of warfarfe presented in PlanetSide 2.

Day one, I spawned in a teleporter... or incubation tube (not really sure on that), and ran out the forceshield door into brillant and beautifully rendered warfare.  I was awestruck at its complexity, scale, and momentum.  I was so awestruck that a sniper killed me... that's ok; time to respawn and go kill a sniper.  Which I did.  Vengence was mine, but I digress.  I took my moment of victory on the mountaintop to look at the field before me.  I saw gunships and Batwing looking jets performing a praticed death dance in the sky.  Tanks, APCs, jeeps, & ATVs were swarming the ground lending their barrage to the base in a sci-fi only version of shock and awe.  Troops were swarming like ants towards the base.  Light infantry using jump jets were taking the parapets above, raining small arms fire down into the interior courtyard of the base.  Heavy infantry, MAXes (infantry in armored suit), medics and engineers were pouring into every openning in the base.  People were dying...

Time to switch to a medic!  Next thing I know, I'm at that base.  Gunfire flying by, explosions all around, and a fallen teammate at my feet.  Don't worry buddy, I'm a medic.  I'll heal you.  I rez him like a pro.  Dagnabit! Someone killed me! Ah, sweet bright light, I'll come towards you.  Wait... that's a medical tool, I'm being rezzed!  Back in the fight!  The impromptu teammate seems to coalesce from nowhere.  Those on your own faction tend to help you whenever they can. Need a ride?  Someone stops to pick you up.  Need repair?  An engineer appears from nowhere to help.  It just happens.  Maybe by design, maybe because everyone realizes that helping you helps them.  I don't know, but it's exactly what should happen.

What something a bit more?  Join an outfit, make friends, blow stuff up together.  PlanetSide 2 is a definate 9/10.  PC Gamer had it right.

reviewText:
First off, if you like Pay to Win games, please leave.

Secondly, if you are expecting the usual MMO be prepared for something completely different.


Now then.

Its going to be hard to describe what I like best about this game... theres just too much of the good stuff going on on all levels. As a free player you will have access to all areas from the beginning, so the progression is all about cool new unlocks and customisation (cosmetics & builds).

One good way to start is to say that it's BIG, and I don't necessarily mean a big map-size (though it doesnt disappoint there either), but more along the lines of a threeway mega multiplayer, with multi-role vehicles and combined arms gameplay. All on an alien world (check out the Hossin continent, I love it!)

The gunplay (real gunplay, not the usual MMO junk) is more like that in the older Battlefield games, you will have to shoot more bullets to get the kill due to personal shields (ala Halo) on all classes. Which is a good since you are going to get shot at a lot :)

I love the Sciency (that's a word) future weapons, the three distinct factions, and the small tactical fights spread out within the ridiculously large strategic battles. If you like shooters you will find something to love here, guaranteed.

The payment model is similar to the one used by League of Legends, in that paying money wont give you any competitive advantage ever. Cosmetics and Weapons can be bought, where the weapons arent straight upgrades but alternative 'sidegrades'. Subsription nets you big XP bonuses, some monthly unlock credits, and access to new stuff (cosmetics only) before anyone else.

NOTE: the default weapons are designed to be the most balanced and flexible in line with your faction's philosophy. If you died to someone at a higher rank, it is because you are a worse player. Repeat there IS NO PAY TO WIN in this game.

The few cons are; that hey its a high end game, you are going to need a really good rig to keep your fps up in the larger battles, and that there is very little hand-holding. Jump on, make friends, squad up, pick your own fights. I hear a lot of people wander around aimlessly wondering what to do - don't be one of those people, it's a game that rewards a little thinking (especially for a beginner) massively.


Come join me on the Miller server (RIP Woodman :s ) and fight under the banner of the Terran Republic!

reviewText:
Let me tell you aout Planetside 2.

As you can probably guess, Planetside 2 is not your average FPS. It's an open world FPS with four continents: Indar,Esamir,Amerish and the newest one, Hossin. Each of them are incredible huge and can fit hundreds upon hundreds of players. There are six classes in total:

Light Assault: your standard assault trooper but with a jetpack, so you can easily get to place to place.
Heavy Assault: Heavy assaults have the 2nd strongest weapons and carry a bazooka with them.
Engineer: Engineer is one of the most important classes. engineers can repair vehicles, set up turrets, repair MAX units, and give other players ammo.
Combat Medic: Combat medics heal other troops and revive them, though they cannot heal a MAX unit
Infiltrator: The Sniper, but he can also turn invisible and hack vehicle terminals. Last, but definitly not least
MAX: The MAX unit is a mech unit and is the strongest in the game, it's normal bullets have the power to take out tanks, but like I said earlier, then can only be healed by engineers.

Now on to the factions and their benefits:

Terran Republic: The Terran republic are the ones who originally governed Auraxis, the planet you play on. They are authoritative, and conservitist. Their weapons fire incredibly fast, but fairly low damage. Their unique vehicles are the prowler and the mantis.

New Conglomerate: The New Conglomerate are a rebel faction who wish independance from the Terran Republic. their weapons are the strongest in the game but have incredibly high recoil. Their unique vehicles are the vangaurd and the reaver.

Vanu Sovereignty: The Vanu Sovereignty use technology found from aliens known as the Vanu. They believe that humanity can only evolve through this technology. they have fast bullets, no bullet-drop and low reload speed. Their unique vehicles are the magrider and the sycthe.

there are many vehicles in Planetside 2,

Flash, An ATM that can be equiped with a weapon, they are fast but not really a good vehicle in comabt
Herasser: The Herasser is more of a car, but still not the best in combat
Lightning: The lightning is a tank, good in combat and one of the most used vehicles.
Sunderer: the most useful land vehicle, this vehicle is slow, but when deployed it is used as a spawn point and you can get ammo from there. It is also used for transport as it can fit an entire squad (12 people)

Air vehicles:

Liberator: a fairly small air vehicle, it is great for attacking land units.
Galaxy: The Galaxy is a huge air vehicle that is used for transport and can also be used as a spawn point.

The goal of the game is to capture points in the continents, there are outposts, bio labs, and other kinds are points.
You can go lone wolf, traveling to places where there is a lot of combat, or join a squad or platoon or better yet, an outfit. An outfit is what you would call a guild in MMO's. An oufit will usually have a lot of players, and a lot of them pros depending on what outfit. Outfits usually have events are depending on how large it is, a lot of platoons. Joining a good outfit will give you a great experience.

This is a fantastic game, incredible large, action packed and not even team-based, but army-based. I highly recommend it to everyone who enjoys FPS and open-world games.

reviewText:
Planet side 2. An amazing game, everyone should try it and formulate their own opinion. For me, though, I feel the game loses a lot of gameplay from the change of 1 to 2. I can imagine why they held off on some of the game play, the cost of production would skyrocket, but what happened to other portions left behind in the first game that were essencial to the experience?

It was a unique experience going from planet side 2 to planet side 1, but I ended up asking myself, What happened? Where did this all go?

I played planet side 1 and never felt once that a kill had been unfair, you had to learn the ropes and you had to change your midset but eventually you could compete and surpass the veterans. Planet side one had a massive amount of different vehicals like a stealth spawn point and a flying brick that can hot drop tanks (Yes, tanks can be loaded and droped from aircraft). Planet side 1 also only gave you certs if you leveled up, and there are no preset classes, so right of the bat you have to specialize to survive. The gun play in the game was tactical and brilliant, it put thought in front of firepower. Bases that were defending took power, and power was regained by people replenishing it with a special vehical, adding a RTS edge. But my favorite part, evenrything was animated, there was not one action that did not have an 1 second animation to back it up, it immersed me in the world without breaking the gameplay.

As I look on planet side 2, I feel the only thing that was made better was the visuals. Which is more then enough to harm the gameplay.

Thats just my opinion, like I said, try the game and formulate your own, maybe you will like it more than I did.

For anyone interested, planet side 1 is free to play. I found a fourm where you can sign up and download it. https://forums.station.sony.com/ps2/index.php?threads/how-to-get-planetside-1.175003/ Give it a try sometime after you played planet side 2.

*Note: I only reinstalled this game because someone said that playing the light assault is like playing as a mandalorian, I realized I had never thought of it like that and imminently installed the game again to play as Boba Fett.

reviewText:
What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said a hundred times?  Yes, it has enormous battles between multiple platoons all at once.  Indeed, I offen feal that those are the battles that keep me playing hoping that the next time i log in will be the next big one and all the little battles in-between almost feal like the warmup to the next.
So, thats what I will talk about.  The little battles.  But first.
Bugs, glitches?  Yes we have them, especially after the game gets updated again.  Witch happes a lot, though most of them will be sorted out within a week...most of the time.....
Lag? Again yes we have that.  Up to 2000 people per map and/or 200 people per side in a three way battle on a piece of land about a mile or two square?  Hit Alt + F and you can literally watch your FPS drop.
Witch in turn leads back to the small battles.  Less people, higher FPS and offen a more personal feal to the fights, especially if you have a working mic or at least have mics turned on so you can hear what those with are saying (unlike some games our chat isn't full of pre-teens swearing their heads off.  Don't get me worng, we have some of them as well, but for the most part their few and far between).  Or mabe you found an enemy bace with no one home and decided to go for whats called a 'ghost cap' and then some one turns up to flush you out and it becomes a fun little 1v1 till some one kicks the other out.
Yes, this is a game about big, big battles.  But that doesn't mean you can find smaller ones to ether take a brake/work your way up to, the bigger ones.
Still reading?  Really?  ....Um....ok....  Well if it is your first time heres two tips that the tutorial (for some odd and some what annoying reason).  First, infiltrators have a 'hack' ability you can use on terminals and turrets to turn them to your side, even when an enemy is in them in witch case they will be kicked out a few feet behind them, you also dont need to be always facing  the target solong as you keep holding the action butten for the hack, usefull for being ready to shoot the person that was in said turret. reviewText:
I have played quite a few free FPS titles. It's strange in some way, due to the fact that I stick to my paid titles a lot more. Regardless, it's interesting to see what works and what doesn't.

PlanetSide 2 has been talked about a lot, probably most notable example would be PC Gamer magazine. Even with that, it took me a while to even decide to pick it up and give it a shot. [Quick note, I don't endorse PC Gamer as a good source of balanced information regarding the game industry, but more of a bulletin for new things].

I was pleased right off the bat from videos to see a high bar set on graphics, effects, and environmental scale. Even PhysX particles added more to the title.

After acquiring the core content from Steam, I was a little struck to see a launcher and updater. While not a huge issue, as many other F2P titles on Steam do the same thing, but it's just more junk on the machine. Downloading through the launcher didn't take that long, and the main menu of sorts was presented to me. This is where things starts to get on loose ground.

The select a server process isn't what it should be. You create a character, decide on 1 of 3 sides, play a tutorial, and then you are let loose into the public game. Unknown to you is that that character has to stay on that server. If you want to hop on a server where your friend plays, you have to create a new character and start all over again. Certainly a bummer when social play" is to be encouraged. Throw in a maximum of 3 characters

recommended: which I haven't been able to find the information release that explains who/what/where/when/why.\n\nInformation overload isn't a major problem with most modern FPS titles

reviewText:
Nice concept, I really tried to like this game.. but I can't recommend it. Especially to new players.. since the experienced playerbase (and well armed, balance is a concern and weapons are NOT always sidegrades) will pound you to the ground at this point.

The gameplay itself is nice and smooth, but it all breaks down to one singular point: Numbers win. That is all and your contribution is completely pointless. Bigger numbers win ten times out of ten and you can do NOTHING about it as an individual. This makes sense, this is how war works and war isn't fair. Unfortunately, this is a video game and some balance has to be made.

So I'll sum up my everyday experience with PS 2. You log in, go into battle. One of 2 things happens.. either numbers are on your side, in which case you completely roll over enemy defences, often supported by vehicles that will be shelling the everliving ♥♥♥♥ out of enemy base (spawn). So they can't even fight back. In this scenario you sit on the point and wait... maybe revive occasional fallen comrade on your side (if you're medic). Fun, fun, fun!

Or.. you find yourself on the receiving end of the same thing. The moment you leave spawn you die to the bombing or the infantry that is camped around the spawn. Even if you manage to flank the enemy.. it's pointless. Maybe you take down a few.. there's still too many of them, you won't break the siege or anything. So you sit there frustrated or you leave for some other base, in which case you roll the dice again which scenario you end up in. Again, fun, fun, fun!

Individuals simply don't matter in this game. Progression is extremely slow with weapons being expensive and currency gain low. This is not such a problem for infantry as most weapon are usable one way or another. But the game changes when it comes to vehicles, some upgrades are absolutely ESSENTIAL to being effective in a vehicle. Until then you won't get far in a vehicle... so how do you earn currency to kit out your ride? Yep, back to the MEAT GRINDER. This game seriously reminds me of the movie Starship Troopes... scores of infantry sent to be slaughtered against even more numerous enemy. It would be almost poetic if it wasn't so bloody frustrating.

Anyway, even when you manage to get that new shiny gun (after a looong time) it won't help you anyway when you are taking potshosts at the camping enemy from the spawn room. reviewText:
Planet Side 2 is all about size. Just 1 of the 3 continents is larger than all the MW3 maps put together. The small skirmishes in this game tend to be 20 on 20, medium ones can easily be 50 plus. But where this game really shines is the big battles. Hundreds of people split up across 3 armies all fighting for control of the same zones with dozens of tanks and aircraft supporting them. If you are a lone wolf you will probably become easily bored, but if you enjoy team/squad based tactics there is nothing on the market that compares with PS2.

The big battles when you get lots of particle effects flying around can be a bit of a resource hog. You also want a broadband network connection, being a shooter latency is very important. The good news if you are unsure about what your system can run the game is F2P so there is no reason not to try it.

The one part we need to keep an eye on is the F2P element. While it is nice that anyone can try it time will tell if it becomes pay to win. So far it does not seem to do that. Mostly you buy XP boosts or cosmetic items. You can spend money on purchasing weapons also, so far there are not that many weapons to purchase and none of those that I have tried have been ridiculously overpowered. Most have trade offs like higher rate of fire but greater bullet spread. In the end they so far seem to balance themselves out.

In the end it is a great change of pace from most all modern shooters on the market. As someone who enjoys being another soldier instead of a 1 man army I find the team based game play to be amazing. If you have the machine to do it the graphics look amazing good at higher settings. The servers also seem to be well made, even in the largest of battles I do not experience any real lag. You will occasionally see the random guy blinking across the battlefield but that is them lagging not the server. I would give it 8.5 if I could but will go with an 8. It has room to improve but so far so good.

reviewText:
Downloaded it a couple days ago, played 16 hours straight, It's very smooth, addicting and huge MMOFPS, It isn't just a FPS, the game works a lot like real war, Infantry need air support and tank support to take locations, in total they're hundreds of locations to take, faction choices are more preference based then gameplay changing based, you get some different looking stuff and some factions have better stats towards items that there faction is advertised to be.

You cannot log into this game as an experienced FPS player and expect to go 40/5 score's like you might in CoD or other related games, this game is about teamplay and stratergy, they're 6 different unit types all of which can counter or push or '' sneak '' the enemy to help your team/group/unit/outfit (clan)/faction take an objective.

I still don't fully understand the game which is a surprise since I'm one of those kind of 40/5 players when it comes to FPS games on the PC, However this isn't a game where you call people noob or get godly scores, infact most people don't get good scores, the game says you can die a hundred different ways and it's practically true, the game is about the real-war vibe, soldiers attacking objectives, dying over and over until air and tank support finally take over.

Sound: 9/10 - Very realistic and immersive, makes you feel like you're in an actual war with the lights off :P
Gameplay: 10/10 - Can feel unfair at times, but the over-all goal and experienced is more then achieved by the game.
Combat: 8/10 - Again can occasionally feel unfair but not unabalanced, luck can help as-well as group play.
Air Combat: - 11/10 - So realistic and responsive, requires a lot of learning and practice to dominate.
Tanks/ETC - 9/10 very realistic but can't be effectively fired using third person, shutting you down from your surrounding
Pay2Win? - This game is free to play, some guns are £ cash only but a lot of guns are In-game credits, you will find yourself somewhat grinding here, I was only able to unlock some gun attatchments and upgrades after 16 hours of gameplay, however the '' beginner '' guns are very good, they're not made crap to force you into buying, you could happily and easily use all the beginner items forever and be a good player, however I feel some cash guns do offer advantages but it's strange, The pace at which someone can die is never changed by the gun, some guns just assist the person, meaning if you're a good FPS player it won't matter, if you're a new FPS player or a bad one, you will often find yourself over-powered by cash users, over-all not anywhere close to P2W.

- PS, The sniper unit can cloak small vehicles and fire from them whilst remaining cloaked, sniper units can also use some rifles, being stealthed with a rifle for me is a broken aspect of this game and one I do not enjoy or support.

- Sniping, it's nothing like call of duty or other FPS games so if you're a quickscoping fanboy don't bother with this game, Sniping is very realistic, you have to aim where your opponent will be, bullet travel time and distance vastly affects your aim, also most beginner snipers do not one shot unless headshot, but do lot's of high damage, which is how it should be, like air combat, sniping actually requires practice.

Over-all rating: 9/10 - Completely free to play, no hackers that are overkilling the game, lots of stratergy, groups and action, Not pay2win, addictive and balanced, feels like CoD + Battlefield, best of both worlds, with slightly less graphics compared to say Battlefield, I'd say on max settings this makes any CoD game look '' simular ''.

Graphics: I have a MSI Nvidia GTX 970 over-clocked at maximum overclock and I get 100-120 FPS with very high settings in fights of 1-12 or 12-24, I get about 60-80 fps in fights of 24-48 and 60-70 in fights of 48-96 and 96+

The textures of the game are somewhat '' ugly '' compared to other games, but this is often misunderstood as a bad thing, you have to load about 30-400 players in one somewhat small objective area at one given time, including the sky, the tanks and turrets, mines, the map itself, the rocks and map design and fillers including helicopters etc ALL MOVING at once, I feel the textures are bad for a reason, the game is unplayable on any standard/none gaming GPU, (AMD/Nvidia) is required at atleast about £70+ per GPU (2 GPU's) or £200+ for one GPU to run the game at an eye pleasing level.

reviewText:
If you've ever looked to a game for large battles with innumerable players and vehicles, Planetside 2 is right for you. Games like Battlefield boast about their epic 64 player battles running smoothly, but Planetside blows this out of the water.

Before Planetside, I had always looked for an FPS that required teamwork and coordination to succeed. Other games may have had some level of this, but none surpassed the level needed to succeed in Planetside. It is not uncommon to find yourself in a platoon cooridinating with over 100 other players in a firefight against another 100 players.

While Planetside may take some time to build up your character (unlocking equipment and vehicle upgrades etc) the time invested is definitely worth it in the long run if you plan on playing a lot. You will also need a decent computer and solid internet connection as well if you want to compete in the large battles.

Overall, I definitely reccomend this game to anyone looking for an FPS that strays from the typical mutiplayer experience.

reviewText:
Great combat system, in-depth customization of nearly every feature the game has to offer (Weapons, vehicles, loadout, and decoration), and a very strong emphasis on cooperation and coordination to win (to the point of absolute necessity -- simply being good AT the game is one thing; being good with other players is quite another).
Furthermore, excellently-designed environment with very-well thought out, varied structures and locations. The three factions (despite the occasional discrepancy) are balanced in a very clever way that makes it so they have equal abilities but different specialities, without each faction seeming to be the same.

BUT, the most outstanding aspect of this game is by far the dedicated moderators and developers, who are in-touch with the playerbase populace to the point of near-telepathy. They consistently make improvements, take criticisms/suggestions, and then incorporate solutions and new ideas into the game in later improvement patches. The Planetside 2 staff are definately on the ball, all the time, and rarely ever (if so, marginally) make mistakes.

When you get on, just make sure to bring some friends, or make some while your there. It compounds the fun.

Certainly well-worth your time. I highly doubt anyone would regret downloading this.  Also, it's free.
