reviewText:
The game works. Though, it's a pain in the ♥♥♥ to get good weapones. And it takes time to learn the game, and you will be dying alot as a beginner, since there are those pay to win players that have overpowered weapones and some of them might have a bit of skill too, witch is quite a deadly combo. Though , as you progress through the game, you will get used to it and get better and better, earn certs and buy different items. I reccomend you to get weapones everyday with the trials, 30 mins per 8 hours seems quite ok to test a weapon on the field. Could be alot better, I am expecting some new types of gamplay, not just capturing all day, the same points, on the same maps. And it's not my job to tell you what to actually make =)

PROS:

+ You can test your weapones before you buy them, on the field !
- Only once per a month for the same weapon, and for only 30 minutes.
+ Good level design
+ Great huge maps to play on
+ Large battles
+ Amazing tank fights
+ Good air battles
+ Good class variation , for diffrent types of playstiles
+ Extraodrinary epic random player-generated fights
+ Average experience in late game, repetitive and frustrating sometimes, though it could be alot worse, so I will put it on the 'bright' side

CONS

- Bad new-player experience
- Very simple combat, not much variation here
- Unbalanced factions
- Average optimization
- Unplayable as an NC newbie
- Alot of pay to win aspects
- Grinding takes too long ( it took me over 2 days to get a 250C rocket launcher, witch is not OK)

Overall , I would give this game a 7 / 10 for it's epic battles.

reviewText:
Updated since the optimization patch in November 2013:

A stunning, action-packed ground & air combat mmo that puts most other shooters to shame.

The sheer vastness of the game worlds, hugeness of the fights, cinematic visual and audio effects and excellent community that puts teamwork over k/d ratio make this one of my favourite games of all time.

Planetside 2 is amazing, if you're not playing it or perhaps havn't tried it since the optimization patch (previously there were huge issues with high end rigs struggling to get 20-30 fps) then try it again, those problems are all in the past and this game deserves lots of love!

Definately recommended, plus it's free2play so it doesn't cost you anything to download and get 100% involved (subscription plans simply increase how many in-game points you earn for new weapon unlocks etc).

9/10 - Amazing, get it!
Excellent work and incredible post-release support, Sony.

reviewText:
This game is ADDICTIVE.You can play tons and not get bored,that is if you have a friend.I have to say the graphics is a amazing,that depends if you have a good gaming pc.Even on low grafics, this game gives you the chance to really become a badass.It gives you a bad time at start but soon you find yourself enjoying after some time.There are 4 MAJOR problems with this game :

1.Station Cash - IT IS WAY TOO OVERPRICED.Most will act like a child telling me its cheap.Its not cheap when 15USD in my place is 50 Dollars.Thats asking me to buy a complete game that gives me anything.Especially when guns cost 7USD and they all look the same,having you to buy a camo which cost you another 500 SC for ONLY ONE OF YOUR CHARACTERS.

2.Certification - If you're playing for free, you are tortured to an eternety to earn Certs especially with guns that cost 1000 CERTS.Having premium membership or a boost will give a bunch in no time but of course you either have to pay 15USD a month or having to pay 250-1000 SC.

3.Faction Biased - You like red? so do I.BUTTTT.Terrain's are given with weapons that arent that powerful as the Vanu or NC.They are only given bonus to the amout of ammo they have.While we have generic Rocket Launchers,the NC & Vanu have tracking missiles that litteraly finds you anywhere.Also Vanu's are a ♥♥♥♥ING ♥♥♥ to see at night,as well as super accuracy and the NC  with Max'es that litteraly take forever to kill

4.Server Maintanace - This is a game breaker.YES I know the game is in Beta.But it shouldnt block us forom playing one WHOLE night.Especially with the frequent planetside 2 maintenance every night .This really breaks the gameplay especially when your in a tense battle almost reaching 1000 certs and boom.YOU DIE.

Even with that,the game is awesome.I highly recommend playing this game.It is a 9/10 If your willing to empty your pockets for the game,8/10 if your playing for free with friends, but 6/10 if playing for free and being alone. The graphics though will have a 10/10 BADASS!!!!

I seriusly recommend playing as TR since they focus on infantry and brotherhood".You will never feel so close to a faction as you do in the TR.

reviewText:
Updated since the optimization patch in November 2013:

A stunning, action-packed ground & air combat mmo that puts most other shooters to shame.

The sheer vastness of the game worlds, hugeness of the fights, cinematic visual and audio effects and excellent community that puts teamwork over k/d ratio make this one of my favourite games of all time.

Planetside 2 is amazing, if you're not playing it or perhaps havn't tried it since the optimization patch (previously there were huge issues with high end rigs struggling to get 20-30 fps) then try it again, those problems are all in the past and this game deserves lots of love!

Definately recommended, plus it's free2play so it doesn't cost you anything to download and get 100% involved (subscription plans simply increase how many in-game points you earn for new weapon unlocks etc).

9/10 - Amazing, get it!
Excellent work and incredible post-release support, Sony.

reviewText:
This game delivers a massive scale of combat with vehicles, aircrafts and infantry. It's possible to have a huge battle between 600 people (300 vs 300), if not more. There are 3 factions each one having its peaceful as well as broken views of the world. Their ideologies are perfectly balanced and in my opinion, no one is neither better nor worse than the others. The more thought is spend on choosing your faction, the more difficult it will seem to make your choice:

-The Terran Republic (TR): The original empire from which people branched off and created the other 2 fronts. On one hand, they want to create peace through fighting, defeating and uniting everyone into one faction under its rule so everyone can equally share the resources of Auraxis. On the other hand, everyone under its reign must follow its ideology, so freedom of choice does not exist and people that are considered a threat are executed. (Peacemakers / Tyrants)

-The New Conglomerate (NC): Freedom fighters originally fighting against the TR for their oppressive views, yet created from corporation leaders and is based on oligarchy. (Rebels / Mercenaries)

-The Vanu Sovereignty (VS): Scientists that discovered alien technology and legitimately want to advance the human race, but at the cost of humanity itself (brainwashing, toying with unknown tech).
(Scientists / Fanatics)

It is definately worth it if you're into these types of games. If you are feeling that your leadership or aiming skills go unacknowledged, don't worry. You can always join an outfit (clan) and play with your buddies. Unlike other games, voice chat communication is constant between leaders and squad members alike.

Also, not to mention that new features are constantly added to the game like cosmetic items, weapons and vehicles ;)

reviewText: Hey, you know how in some shooters, you end up bored trying to find enemies. Or that you feel that you are not really playing a very important role. Well not more! Planetside 2 is the successor of Planetside (a game I know nothing about). It combines fast-paced gameplay with a variety of classes. Instead of your normal small map Deathmatch, the map is F**KING HUGE! Seriously, you can get lost extremely easily. Now, you can still spend tons of time looking for something to kill, but that is overlooked thanks to Instant Action (a little feature that puts you in a very populated battle). There are 3 factions: The Red dudes with attitude (and bullets), the Blue rebels with tons of damn armor, and my personal favorite, the Purple men with PEW PEW laser guns. The classes include a sniper that can g invisible, a fast dude with a jetpack, a medic that is quite good at combat, an engie that can deploy a turret (TF2 much?), a guy like the fast dude, but with more armor, no jetpack, and a motherf**king rocketlauncher. Oh yeah, then there is the MAX, an overpowered fighting machine, aka the Heavy from TF2. The vehicles are cool, ranging from a little quad bike to giant transport ships. Overall, I quite like Planetside 2. Too bad not a lot of people play. I mean, ONLY 3,000 players on Steam??? Isn't this a MMOFPS? Anyway, I'm Soulhero, and I'll see you later Wanderers!

reviewText:
The game is fantastic but be sure you've got a couple things before diving in:

A computer beefy enough to handle high or greater graphical settings, because as gorgeous as the game is, on low settings the textures are washed out trash.  Though on high settings or greater, you're going to be in for a treat with it's crisp and stunning visuals, like a rainbow threw up on Battlefield 3 and put the fight on an alien world.

You need to want to be a team player.  Your experience in this game will vary dramatically from enthralling and heartpounding to just plain frustrating and rage inducing, and the difference is teamwork.  Find an outfit (a guild) and communicate with them using the robust in-game voicechat.  Hop in a platoon and look for your leaders' waypoints.  Stick with your team and you'll have a ball.

The last thing you'll need is patience.  You're going to take a while to get used to the game and all of the systems in place.  Familiarize yourself with the map and the different functions around the bases.  Ask questions in voice-chat.  If you can find a friend that can help familiarize you with the icons around a base, they can get overwhelming.

Good luck out there if you choose to play, it's a great game and even more incredible that they're offering it for free, and I'll say that the paid character cosmetic customizations are quite worth it, they certainly make you stand out without being obstructive.

reviewText:
This game is a welcome part in the already full genre of First Person Shooters. The reason I liked it above other Triple A titles, is that it has a more expansive map. The game is also heavy on the enviroment. Next to the otherwise beautiful landscapes, from desert like to jungle, the game has an added day/night cycle. This is a feature I've not seen in any Multiplayer FPS. Gameplaywise, the game feels like any shooter, but with the extended class customization the game does not feel like one weapon is the best.

I also might add that the vehicles feel smooth to use. The fighter jets do what you want them to do. Vehicle combat feels as if you're the supportive brother, and not OP on any side.

I give an advise to beginner players, players who aren't skilled enough and players who like to know their preferred class to use VR training, which gives you access to all equipment and training dummies, which is a great training.

One downside I found, is that the microtransactions brake the progress of your character a bit. But if you aren't into any special grinding, (which you do not have to be, because the standard weaponry work fine.), you almost do not notice it.

I've not checked the friends and squads part of the game, but it looks very extensive.

All and all I would give this game a try. even the Tripple A fans. Because it delivers on all FPS standards, with having the advantage of being free to play.

reviewText:
After having played +300 hours I can say that this is most likely the best F2P Shooter ever created so far. The easiest comparison is with Battlefield. It's pretty much Battlefield in a Sci-Fi setting and HUUUUUGE! Each of the current four continents spans 64 square kilometers with many bases and outposts ranging from small forward outposts to large tech plants. Combine this with a unique look to each continent plus three factions longing for control over the territory, most of the time having two or more fronts to battle at, and very good game balancing and you get Planetside 2.
The only real downside to the game are the required system specs. The game is pretty performance-hungry, but the devs are working in improving the games performance constantly.

If you're not a Lone Wolf type of player you might want to grab some friends or find an outfit to roll with tho, because there's only so much you can do by yourself. Sometimes a coordinated air raid or tank convoy is the thing you need and you can't do this as effectively when you're alone.

reviewText:
Massive eternal war.

Presentation: 7
The game was released in 2012 so the graphics are not as good as it would be if it was released today, but because it was PC exclusive back then the graphics have aged well and are still quite good. The audio was fairly good to begin with and has been updated several times to be even better. Each faction has unique designs for their soldiers, weapons and vehicles. Each continent has a unique climate and look.

Gameplay: 7
It's a class/loadout based shooter like battlefield with land and air vehicles. It also now features resource gathering and base building. Battles are not usually determined by individual skill, but by the amount of players and the equipment available to the players. Battles can contain hundreds of players.

Story: 5
The different factions don't like one another because of political differences. It's a multiplayer only game without characters, so players are left to create their own stories.

Total: 6.7/10

reviewText:
Planetside 2 is... in simple terms, a very solid and entertaining free to play FPS game.

Pros:
+Solid weapon variety, yet, almost all weapons are side-grades or specializations, meaning you're not at any disadvantage just because you're using starting gear.
+Alright faction flavor, unfortunately a bit watered down for reasons I'll get to later.
+Reasonable weapon customization options, typically allowing you to specialize a weapon towards either hipfiring or aiming down the sights, then with some weapons shifting their damage profile towards close range or long range focus.
+Very good design on ground vehicles, other than the ATVs that can mount weapons and cloak they all feel rather fun to fight against or alongside, or to drive and gun yourself. They look nice too.
+The game rewards teamwork strongly and has good mechanics for implementing it, you can even just jump into a random squad by pressing 'insert' at any time if you're playing solo. Solo play is entirely workable in my opinion as well, but requires more map awareness.
+Massive battles, during busy hours there can be multiple 100v100 fights going on around the very large map.


Cons:
-The faction flavor is slightly watered down by the presence of Nanite Systems (adaptation of the abbreviation for Non Empire Specific or Non Specific" weapons) guns. I would describe these as "Call of Duty guns" to properly capture their role in the game. They're bland

reviewText:
You need to try this game just for its legit unqiue experience. I've never played or seen anything else that provides an FPS experience with hundreds to thousands of player combatants present. There's no NPCs. Its much more like experiencing a real(ish) war. The massive scale vehicle battles in particular are things you just have to be there for.

That said, its a cruel game. Time to kill is on average less than a second so its high lethality. You'll die a lot and often in bitter ways. However, the kills you do get are gonna feel awesome.

Its not a newb friendly game and your mad FPS skills won't help ease that much. Pro tip: Get in and use the social tab to join a public platoon. Strength in numbers is vital. Running around with a group of experienced players will definitely get you the best experiences PS2 has to offer. Run around alone and you'll probably just be wasting your time.

Public platoons are very forgiving and nice. You don't need voip to participate, you can hop in and out as you need and no one will care. Just make sure to stay with the group. No one like a squad-mate who runs off alone all the time.

reviewText: Planetside 2 fulfills all the 'standard' FPS requirements of modern gaming. There's guns, there's violence, and finally, there's shenanigans. If you don't know what I mean by that, then you've never found a creative or humiliating way to kill someone in a game (of which Planetside 2 has plenty.) It goes above and beyond by having a balanced class structure, with all six classes having a distinct role in combat. With that said, and the aforementioned insane amount of weapons, attachments, and not to mention cosmetic items, you can play this game pretty much however you want. Want to spear the assault and go in guns blazing? Check. Want to be that sneaky, shady guy in the corner, promoting open-mindedness one bullet at a time? Check. Or maybe you want to be some form of support, either by repairing things or patching up people? Yup, it's got those too. The vehicles are very well implemented, too, allowing you to rule the skies in either fighter aircraft, gunships, or a large troop transporter. Add in tanks, buggies, ATV's, and a combat bus (No, I'm not making that up) and you make for an insanity-fest just waiting to happen. Oh, and the absolutely massive battles don't help this. Sometimes, you're in three man skirmishes, and other times... you just run face-first into an armored column of no less than thirty tanks. It's big, it's scary, and damn if it isn't fun. Even better, it's FREE! (As in, no money, no problems.)

reviewText:
Massive eternal war.

Presentation: 7
The game was released in 2012 so the graphics are not as good as it would be if it was released today, but because it was PC exclusive back then the graphics have aged well and are still quite good. The audio was fairly good to begin with and has been updated several times to be even better. Each faction has unique designs for their soldiers, weapons and vehicles. Each continent has a unique climate and look.

Gameplay: 7
It's a class/loadout based shooter like battlefield with land and air vehicles. It also now features resource gathering and base building. Battles are not usually determined by individual skill, but by the amount of players and the equipment available to the players. Battles can contain hundreds of players.

Story: 5
The different factions don't like one another because of political differences. It's a multiplayer only game without characters, so players are left to create their own stories.

Total: 6.7/10

reviewText:
This game at launch was a piece of crap.  A piece of crap the likes of which no one had seen before! Unfortunately, MOST people who tried this game out had debilitating lag, crippling FPS, and thus a terrible experience.  Since Performance Update 1 (OMFG patch), my FPS with a medium-of-the-line computer are 60+ all of the time, often at 100+.  If you tried it back at launch and couldn't play, I would heartily recommend you fire it up.

As far as the gameplay, PS2 is insanely fun. The vehicles in this game are fun to drive, the gunplay is very responsive, and overall the progression is very good (You could argue that the game is P2W, but only until you learn how to make certs efficiently).

The Devs in the game are very responsive on their forums or reddit, and crippling bugs are usually patched next day, with medium ones being patched within the week. This is a huge game, so there are MANY smaller bugs, but they seldom are more than an annoyance.  There are very few hackers in the game, or at least ones that are around for more than a week or so.  Aimbotting used to be very prevalent, but has died down; the only real form of cheating is lag switches now, which are very hard to detect.

Probably the worst part of this game is the balance of both the factions and the weapons.  In essence, one faction (NC) has been at a disadvantage for more than 6 months by almost all statistics, and yet have received very little in the way of major buffs or nerfs. I am not part of this faction, so I'm not just QQ'ing; it's pretty widely known by those who regularly like to peruse stats.
In addition, 'cheesy' weapons that allow one to farm certs very quickly are frequently put into the game/made by overbuffing that cause massive unrest in the community (the forums warrior-ism in this game is very strong) leads to a 'flavor of the month', as they are later nerfed. These weapons WILL make you mad, regardless of your rank, but if you stick with it, you can BE that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!

If you can get past your first couple hours, join an outfit, play with your squad, and learn the ropes, you almost certainly will have fun with this game!

reviewText:
If you've ever played and enjoyed Starwars: Battlefront in your nostalgic childhood days, then PlanetSide 2 may very well be in your ball park, and will knock several home runs to boot. It will blow your ideas of massive scale battles in a video game out of the water, rivalled only by a few select titles. Soon upon entry you will learn that as a singular soldier your affect on the waging war is minuet at best, but your duty as an individual in a faction is as important as the people fighting by your side.

PlanetSide 2 is a game best played when working with others, or simply causing havoc with your friends. There's no feeling that can compare to flying well above the ground in a gunship, firing off rounds from a Dalton - an explosive cannon - upon the unsuspecting targets below. Well co-ordinated attacks see uncountable masses of tanks rolling across the continent, much to the defender's disdain. The sheer scale of PlanetSide is impressive at its worst, spectacular at its best.

Being a free-to-play MMO, the war never ceases. There is a vast pool of weapons, resources and upgrades at your disposal. Station cash makes for the inevitable real-world currency of an MMO, allowing you to boost your experience or purchase vanity items. Everything else can be bought with Certs, a currency that is earned through play. In the end, the experience you have or wish to have is entirely up to you.

All in all, fun game download it and blast some people

Has it changed? Not really, it's still pretty laggy and I just can't get it over 35 fps in fights and that's quite dissapointing...
But if you don't really care about that (like me) you should be fine :)

Gameplay:
The gameplay is good, it's just a good first person shooter with alot of people in one war to conquer a whole map.
The battles are huge with sometimes 50 vs 50 and you will obviously die alot but it's not frustrating to die like in other games where you want to throw the controller (or whatever is on your desk) away.

Graphics: I have almost everything on Ultra and then the game will look very nice and detailed.
Effects and explosions are realistic but I'm not so pleased with the sound (it's okay but not great)

Final verdict: Great game but you will need a serious PC if you want to enjoy the most out of the game.
Specs: Pentium G3258 (overclocked, 8GB Crucial Ballistix and the GTX 750Ti.

reviewText:
Planetside 2
On a planet with similar climate properties as earth, there are 3 factions fighting over multiple facilites in territories (regions) in which they can annex and capture and expand their grasp of the surface area in these 4 continents that are snow, desert, forest, and swamplike environments. The game spans to thousands of people per server, resulting in a massive battlefield atmosphere.. Classes, Fleets of gunships, convoys of tanks, platoons of troops etc.

The gameplay itself is solid, with bulletdrop on many weapons and movement being comparable yet sub-par. For example, you can scale sides of cliffs of infantry while standing on nothing but thin air. But that doesn't bother me at all, because doing that gives me an advantage for good sniping spots.

Moving onto the dynamics... this game is FREE-TO-PLAY! Which is great, having any one of my friends just hop in and play. There are 15$ month memberships and bundles where the per month price decreases the more you subscribe.. And there is also the daybreak cash premium currency, this is mostly useless unless you wish to buy decoratives or armor for your character, and new camos. But everything else that actually affects gameplay can be acquired by Certs (In-game credit points) for every 250 experience you earn.

For the graphics and optimization of the game... The game itself is poorly optimized but if you do run it at highest settings it does look pretty damn good. On my gtx 460 i ran it at straight up medium settings with about 35 fps, but now with a gtx 970, it is absolutely amazing at max.

Now to summarize this game up, it is a must download and try out for sure.. deff the best MMOFPS i've played, and when it was first released in 2012, i thought it was ahead of it's time, and in some aspects it still is. There may be a feel of repetition and grinding when you're playing by yourself, but once you get a great group of friends going you'll find yourself putting countless hours into the game.

reviewText: Welcome to Planetside 2, the Massively immersive Multiplayer First Person Shooter... whatever. This game is many things, but the simplest idea for any new players is the scale. You'll truly feel small when hundreds, I mean HUNDREDS of players fight from futuristic tanks, on jetpacks, heavy bombers, starcraft dropships and from mechanized war suits. In the midst of the chaos, you'll truly feel what a real FPS should feel like, not some tight urban corner fight with assault rifles, but a environmental integration of combined arms combat. Enjoy the thrill of joining into outfits, and join a community of diverse players, from BR 100 elitist players whose KD means more than gold, to the vast ranks of zerg squads to change the tide of the fight through the number of bodies you can throw at the enemy. Enjoy the diversity of the three empires: the Vanu, an unbalanced faction of zero recoil pea shooters and neckbeards so thick you think they are the Canadian Confederacy. The Terran Republic, a militaristic faction of farm flyers and terrifying zerg outfits. The New Conglomerate, whose completely dysfunctional leadership is only countered by their freedom to accuracy ratios on their weapons. Revel in the 4 well designed continents that mostly are never used because only Indar has enough fights. Engage in a highly integral multiplayer experience, from drunk squads lead by sloshed leaders and their even more wasted compatriots, to elite platoon whose only difference from the military is physical activity. In this crazy universe of perpetual war, load your gun, strap on your max suits, grab those frags, and prepare to drop into the most unique FPS of all time.

reviewText:
Rewriting because I guess I didn't give enough justice, huh.

Planetside 2 is a massive game unlike anything you've ever played. If you ever think you've played something like it then no, you haven't. If you think you wil be automatically good when you play it, you won't. The learning curve is incredibly steep, and the fact is that skills you learn in Planetside will not transfer over to other games, simply because the game is unlike anything else.

SOE at times seems like a mindless company. Their executive decisions are questionable to say the least, but they're managed to maintain Planetside as an enjoyable experience. Its uniiqueness is what brings it most of its flavour. That's really what killed it. Your experience playing Planetside 2 will be unlike anything you've seen. Planetside 2 is like the little girl you knew growing up. She was proper and loved by everyone in Elementary and Middle School, and especially by you, but when you got to High School she all of a sudden turned into a crack♥♥♥♥♥. Playing Planetside is similar in that you become so attached to the game (If you don't quit immediately after getting dominated constantly and refusing to learn the game) and cry when you see the incompetence of the executive team and theoretically watching your true love get ♥♥♥♥♥ by a gorilla in front of you.

The FPS mechanics in this game are among the highest tier of modern FPS games. The gunplay is smooth and feels right. There are times where you'll be fun policed by zergs, vehicles, liberators, but overall infantry fights, if you ever manage to find any, are very good, And If you ever manage to find any" brings us to our next paragraph.

Populations are... fluctuated. I'm lucky because Connery is the biggest server in the game and that's the server I play on. You can find a fight for the most part at any time of the day. This is different from what I've read up on other servers

reviewText:
When it's dark – properly dark – you can look up at the night sky and see a multitude of stars. Stop and consider those stars. Each one is a ball of superheated gas, floating out there in space with its own history. It's a staggering realisation.

Stop for a second in PlanetSide 2 and you'll see a similar thing, except instead of stars, you're seeing people. Real people, just as out of reach in their homes to you as those stars. Stand and stare up at the sky and you might see a Belgian kid hurtle overhead, chased by a Spanish man in a fighter jet. As the Spanish man's rockets connect with his fuselage, the Belgian kid will wink out of existence like a star going out.

Every light in the sky, every light on the ground, is another person. PlanetSide 2 is a massively multiplayer first-person shooter, and although it's identical in concept to the original PlanetSide: three factions wage eternal war on the ground and in the air over a handful of continents, it feels like the future of games. PlanetSide was crippled by 2003's technology; PlanetSide 2 has the benefit of nine years of human advancement.

Hundreds of players fight across three continents. Indar is red and dusty, Mars with a few scrubby trees. Amerish is green, verdant, and liberally coated in dense jungle. Esamir is icy and beautiful, lit by northern lights at night and reflected sun glare during the day. Each continent is studded with bases of varying size that one of three sides - the militaristic Terran Republic, the self-righteous New Conglomerate and the alien-humping Vanu Sovereignty - can capture. Capturing bases bestows resource bonuses that pay out every few minutes. Those resources can then be used to buy vehicles and infantry supplies from designated terminals found around the huge map, all facilitating PlanetSide 2’s central tenet: a vast, unfurling war between hundreds of players at once, the largest scale of battle yet seen in games outside of EVE Online’s wild space.

I never thought it'd work. PlanetSide 2 is an MMO, it has hundreds of players living on a small amount of global servers – but it also has twitchy combat, bullets based on real physics, and the kind of vehicle fights that demand split second reactions. Few games have combined the two concepts well. The original game used behind-the-scenes number-magic that left weapons feeling toothless and combat floaty.

PlanetSide 2's weapons feel neither toothless nor floaty. They feel like weapons, guns that fire projectiles where you aim them. As a heavy assault class soldier, your bullets will slice through the shield and skin of an enemy at close range. As a sniper toting a powerful enough rifle, a bullet aimed slightly above the head of a long-range target will arc down into their visor to score you a one shot kill.

PlanetSide 2 has five classes, including the snipey Infiltrator, the chunky Heavy Assault, with Light Assault, Medic, and Engineer rounding out the group. Spawn as one of these and head to a re-arm station and you’ll be able to play in the clothes of the sixth class: the MAX suit. These lumbering beauties pack a heavy weapon glued to each arm, and act like walking tanks - softer targets than their angry house friends, but able to dish out exponentially more punishment than regular armour-clad types.

Infantry combat isn't perfect. Some intangible element – either developer SOE's inexperience with modern shooters or the sheer size of the game – means that PlanetSide 2's guns lack the raw punch of a smaller scale FPS. Call of Duty has this down to an exact science. There, I can almost feel the bullets piercing the organs of my enemies. Here, it's closer to Battlefield 3, and not quite as powerful in sensation.

Also like Battlefield 3, death is accompanied by pre-canned animation. Snuff it and your avatar flops to the floor, arm out like a bad movie death. Somehow, it makes you feel powerless and frustrated, your own star winking out of existence.

But these are tradeoffs I'll happily make for the game's scale. I've fought shotgun duels in four-foot wide corridors, but I've also lanced someone in the head from five hundred metres away, ending the digital life of a far off francophone. Infantry combat is wild and crazy and freeform in an intoxicating way, taking place at all distances and in all settings.

reviewText:
Starting off, if you do not have a decent computer, then this game probably is not the game for you.

Planetside 2 is a MASSIVE online multiplayer, strategic first-person shooter, where the goal is simple and the answer is anything but. The goal: capture more territory for your faction, which is one of three themed teams. Territories are captured by captureing points points in a king of the hill and CTF kind of way. Each territory has between 1 and 3 points that are captured by being withing a ccertain distance of a point. After that, it can take up to 5 minutes for the territory to be completely captured. The only hard part is how you achive this goal and fend off players who are constantly running back from their spawn room or Sunderrer (a truck) Mobile Spawnpoint. This is the hard part about this is the route that you take to do this.


First off, there are 3 factions who each have their own benefits, art style, and specalizations.

The Vanu Sovreignty (VS) are a spandex peoples who believe that technology is the most important thing when it concerns the evolution of society. Their weapons boast little bullet drop, and quick reload speeds. They also have some AOE guns (exploding plasma shots).

The New Conglomerate (NC) are the liberators, fighting for freedom. They have low fire rates with hard hitting weapons combined with huge magazines. Just be prepared for the rediculous reload times. Also the NC are VERY fond of shotguns.

The Terran Republic (TR) are fighting for something (justice I think???). They have high fire rates and are very fond of chainguns.

Personally I specialize in being a close range infiltrator (they have lower health but have sheilds). SMGs while expensive, are excellent killing machines. The other classes are the light and heavy infantry, engineer, medic, and MAX. Each class has it's specific guns, abilities, and uses.

The difficult thing about Planetside 2 is that positioning is vitally important. After about 250 hours I started getting the flow of the game. By 400 hours I was finally starting to mantain a KD above 1. This game has a steep learning curve and will take a lot of getting used to. However, I see the 500+ hours completely worth it and can't wait till summer so I can play this a lot more.

reviewText:
In terms of gameplay style, this is very much like Battlefield. Several classes, all with unique perks (medkits, ammo resupply, turrets, anti-vehicle weapons, cloaking, jetpacks, and more), as well as ground vehicles and air vehicles made for either transportion and combat, and one of them even acts like a tanky spawn point for spawing in for battles so you don't have to walk all over or drive to where the fighting is.

The unique aspects of Planetside 2 come from the faction system and the continents present in the game. Every faction is unique in just about every aspect, from voices available, to armor, weapons and weapon functions, and even the sound they make when you coak as an infiltrator. Each faction fights for control of the continents on the planet, and after any faction reaches 15 VP (Victory Points)  on one continent, that continent is locked down and they gain a passive buff, such as health regeneration or reduced cost for air/ground vehicles. Only two continents can get locked down at a time, and they eventually unlock to be fought over once more. Battles in this game are huge, and can get VERY hectic, so expect your FPS to drop pretty fast once the fighting starts getting bigger and bigger (the game is pretty optimized though!)

Being a F2P shooter, one might expect that its pay to win but thankfully its far from it. The progression in this game doesn't change whether you pay or don't, it only becomes faster. All weapons in this game are considered side-grades, that are only bought to complement a specific playstyle rather than be a straight buff to damage or handling. While you can buy weapons with cash rather than certs, all of it is easily obtainble by just playing. You can get by in this game with just the default weapons with a few attachments of your choosing and do just fine. You buy weapons and attachments with certs, which are also used to upgrade a class of your choosing. The upgrades can be passive, like resistance to infantry arms to reduce damage, increased ammo storage, or quicker shield regen. Active upgrades, such as the jump jets for the Light Assault, allow the class to manuever in air with less downtime at higher ranks and quicker regeneration; or the Heavy Assault to get an extras shield ability that allows them to mitigate more damage.

The game lacks a proper tutorial, however, which is sort of the downfall of it. Even the Koltyr planet, meant for newbies, doesn't seem to do much as they encourage you to simply hop into battle. Still, the game is basic enough and there are plenty of guides out there to help familarize yourself with classes, their abilities, and much more. This review only glosses over some of the things in this game, there is still quite a bit of things here like base building/construction, vehicle progression (they also take certs and can be specialized!), customization, etc.

reviewText:
Just 18 hours. Not kidding. But here is my review for this wonderful game.

I MIGHT UPDATE THIS THE MORE I PLAY PLANETSIDE 2.

PROS:
1000s of players at once
FREE TO PLAY
Good enough graphics for me
Good gameplay
NEW CONSTRUCTION SYSTEM
Fun with friends

CONS:
Bad optimization (TRICK: Right click Planetside 2's process, click Set Affinity then uncheck the first core or CPU 0")
Some weapons/vehicles are OP or UP.
Some P2W stuff (What can you expect? It's F2P.
Requires real good PC (You can't handle 1000s of players on that old PC man.)

GAMEPLAY
It's 3 factions fighting it out on a bunch of continents seeking to conquer it all. It plays like a futuristic version of Heroes and Generals. It's weapons are good but some are underpowered or overpowered. If you have some friends who have this game
date:
you could ask them to play with you and all of you can have fun stuff to do as a squad.

GRAPHICS
It's pretty cool. It's pretty much from my experience your usual 2012 game graphics.

FACTIONS
The New Conglomerate is you can imagine as your typical balanced empire.
The Vanu Sovereignty is the tech-savvy guy. Imagine it as that guy who sits on the PC all day and making Harry Potter stuff.
The Terran Republic basically is the Soviet Union + Futuristic tech. That double-barrelled tank tho.

CLASSES
Light Assault is the guy who goes around the frontlines flanking enemies. I picture him as my run and gun guy.
Engineer is that guy who can build you almost anything. Combine the future with him and you got PS2's engineer.
Medic is self-explanatory. Run around shooting enemies while healing your mates.
Infiltrator is that creepy guy who follows you around wanting to know your secrets. In PS2 his job is slightly different.
Heavy Assault is the light assault big brother. He's more better off in a head-on attack rather than flanking.
Max I do not know yet. Never played him yet but due to his name I picture him as a juggernaut.

So I say this game is: (DRUM ROLL)
9/10: Worth trying.

NOTE! I HAVEN'T PLAYED THIS GAME THAT MUCH YET SO I HAVE TO PLAY MORE TO LEARN MORE ABOUT THE GAME. LOOK AT MY TOTAL HOURS! 18 HOURS!
Meh. That's as much as I can think of. As more as I play this game

reviewText:
If your looking for a first person shooter, you need to try Planetside 2. It's the ultimate FPS that throws you into adrenaline fueled battles on an epic scale. Forget Call of Duty or Battlefield, in Planetside 2 you can drop anywhere you want across 4 different continents where there are litterally thousands of players desperately fighting over control with intense infrantry, tank and air battles dotting the beautifully crafted landscape.

Also unlike other FPS, Planetside 2's starting weapons are actually good, this is no 'Pay-2-Win' game. There are no better or worse weapons, just different unlocks to suit different needs & playstyle. These weapons are free to unlock using cert points gained from fighting. This can be slow for the first week until you get used to the game then they start to flow in very quickly as you find the class or vehicle that suits you best.

This game heavily relies on teamwork and communication. While you don't need a microphone, it is important that you use the in-game chat system to coordinate with your team and to find a good outfit to work with. There are plenty of outfits out there that take on new players and will even teach them a few things in-game.

But the best thing about Planetside 2, it's 100% completely free.

If you interested in trying the game and my review has helped in any way, feel free to message me via steam and I'll pass on a recruitment link to create your account which gives you a free in-game bonus starter gear pack for some free unlocks including 3 extra weapons and an experience booster to get you started.

Going to make it brief here, so don't expect a thourough review here.
Like most people say, the game is unique, and most fps games don't come close to being a copycat of it. It is special and that makes for interesting content. But it has some very serious and hurting game foundation problems. Firstly, don't expect to play this game on a laptop nor low budget gaming pc. The game is amazing when it comes down to it, with alot of variety in game play, all the way from different styles of playing as infantry, or with different vehicles.
If you have a clan or play with friends, there is room for alot of strategic game play, or just goof around.
Do i recommend this game? Yes i do. If you look passed it's problems, the game has way too many possibilites.
If you have the specs for it, give it a go! Make sure to bring a friend or two, it gets boring alone :/

reviewText:
Many wonders happen in this game.

To sum it all off, I would not recommend this game if you play alone with or without friends because it just stinks. This game requires communication, cooperation, and teamwork (also a good computer that can run the game) to start doing some real damage to the warring factions. The three main factions are, Vanu Sovereignty, Terran Republic, and New Conglomerate. Each of these factions have personalized weapons, vehicles, and clothing to suit that you are different from them. The Vanu Sovereighnty are the most hi-tech faction from all of them, they have hover tanks, plasma weapons, and scythes which are the most OP air vehicle known to Planetside 2. Terran Republic is a strong faction that wants to reunite all to one flag, they have awesome weaponry (like the burst fire pistol), good mechs, and good tanks. Finally, the New Conglomerate is almost exactly like Terran Republic, but they are rebelling against them calling them tyrants, they do have the same Things as the Terran Republic, but AWESOME THEME MUSIC, that music could switch a battle (it's that good lol).

Once you pick a faction you will be set off in the world of in 4 continents (don't worry they are adding more), these feel almost like planets because they are so different and are so huge. The first continent is Indar which is a mix of deserts and canyons. The 2nd continent is Esamir, which is just a barren frozen wastland. The 3rd continent is Amerish just imagine this continent as Earth a very green place indeed. The last continent is Hossin which is newly added, and is a riddled with MASSIVE trees and swampy lands.

Finally, you will just be battling in one of four continents claiming all the land against the other opponent factions. Most of the time you will be fighting in large numbers (even ranging from 200 player battles). That's a lot, but the most trickest thing about this game is the weapon unlocking system. If you get enough certification points you can unlock/upgrade pretty much anything that kills anyone or makes it harder for enemies to kill you. It's just that you don't get enough to even get a game, it would probably take 2 weeks to get a gun on this game if you were playing everyday for +5 hours. They really need to fix that too, you can of course buy the weapons with station cash, but that is overpriced as well because a gun may cost $10, just for a gun... So beware of that. Other than that everything is perfect and rememberable.

NOW GO SOLDIER FIGHT AND LIVE ON!

Once you pick a faction you will be set off in the world of in 4 continents (don't worry they are adding more), these feel almost like planets because they are so different and are so huge. The first continent is Indar which is a mix of deserts and canyons. The 2nd continent is Esamir, which is just a barren frozen wastland. The 3rd continent is Amerish just imagine this continent as Earth a very green place indeed. The last continent is Hossin which is newly added, and is a riddled with MASSIVE trees and swampy lands.

Finally, you will just be battling in one of four continents claiming all the land against the other opponent factions. Most of the time you will be fighting in large numbers (even ranging from 200 player battles). That's a lot, but the most trickest thing about this game is the weapon unlocking system. If you get enough certification points you can unlock/upgrade pretty much anything that kills anyone or makes it harder for enemies to kill you. It's just that you don't get enough to even get a game, it would probably take 2 weeks to get a gun on this game if you were playing everyday for +5 hours. They really need to fix that too, you can of course buy the weapons with station cash, but that is overpriced as well because a gun may cost $10, just for a gun... So beware of that. Other than that everything is perfect and rememberable.

NOW GO SOLDIER FIGHT AND LIVE ON!

reviewText:
After playing some more I have to change my review. I have found out, that when I just started, I was simply very very unlucky, with bad player, low pop and some issues. Then I had a whole new experience. It seems I started playing in the middle of some patching and maintenance.

I joined the server. There was a full scale battle with all three factions fighting. I joined a squad, which I didnt even need to, due to the massive action, but I did it, to feel as part of something. Very cool experience. There was teamwork to some degree, and our medic was very awake and useful, even though he was very low level like me (by this I mean, I think he hadn't played for long). There were ally squads everywhere, and it reminded me about the long intro in Saving Private Ryan. The enemy attacked with tanks in the distance, while infantry units tried to move in on us. Apparently, and to my favor, it was us defending a huge base. Seemed like a key point to control. I don't know.

I started out by Infiltrator. What fun gameplay I had. I died a lot, yes, but I am aware this is a game pretty close to the real thing. I was suprised over how well I did. I managed to find very good sniper-spots, and remember this is in the middle of a full scale battle, and i man FULL SCALE battle. Bombs, explosions, bullets and flying light infantry everywhere. I think I was lucky, and the enemy was focused elsewhere, but I managed to use the surroundings, instead of my cloak. I got a lot of kill there. 13 or or, which is pretty much for me. I then went into our base, and found what previously looked, and seemed, like poor building design, suddenly showed huge sniping potential, and great structual design, with a lot of planning behind it. I felt like a coward, just sitting in here, in safety. I shifted to infrantry. Oh boy do they have it hard.

It is very hard being infrantry, and being so new that you do not know the surroundings that well yet. Yet I stuck to my group, got split up, united again and fought our way over a bridge. I died a lot, but a well praised medic, kept us alive. This was war. This was awesome. The Light Infrantry clearly is better, the more you know how to control the class, and know the enviroment. It is hard, and unforgiving at first, but you then get to know how to utilize the jetpack, and mobility to evade death. You/I most absolutely have to train a bit, but then you should be fine. I got some kills, around 5. Notice that I almost never kill an enemy alone. It is all about teamwork. This can be frustating, but if you like teamwork, it is no problem. Yet I was lucky to be the one dealing the final bullet a lot.

I felt the other Light Infrantry in our squad did a much better job than I. Both at killing and surviving. This might be due to them being higher lvl. This has nothing to do with the lvl, just that they have played longer and knows the game better than me, therefore I felt I didn't do much. So I changed class to be of better use. I mean we already had well trained light infrantry. I chosed medic. Our medic had dissappeared, so why not.

It is few games where support roles are fun, and even tactical to play, but damn medic in this game is cool as hell. You don't just throw health-packs and sit back in safety. NO you have to go with them straight into battle and grow some soldier balls. We ended up on a stone kind of pillar. We had a bit of shielding from ground infrantry. Yet snipers, and units had a good shot, if we did not crouch. We also took some bad aimed tank shots. I was glued to the ground, crouching and dodging to stay alive. My squad was shooting Rambo-style and doing one hell of a job, also when close-encounter ambushed jump down onto our stone-pillar. Everytime they died, and they died a lot, I would revive them, and try to keep them constantly healed. It worked and I am pretty sure that we were able to hold that piece of the base secure, for at least a little while :) It felt as we did something for the Colony, even though we payed with our lives.

I noticed that high ranking players takes no ♥♥♥♥ at all. I was, in panic, shooting unscoped at a infiltrator trying to melee an ally high rank. I managed to kill the INF, but was executed by my ally high rank, as I had also hit him. I would personally not act like this. It is a bit Eric Cartman-style. Other than that 1 incident, I actually didn't get teamkilled at all. This is wierd since it was all out total chaos. I want to thanks the players online for that. Good Game.

I did not play the other classes, as I still think I need to get to know the game more. Therefore I will focus on 2 classes, maybe 3 with the medic.

I had a very fun time, and will join the game again later. I just kept thinking about, with this little urge to just give it one more try. It worked, and I am beginning to like this game a lot. It really gives some unique and incredible huge battles, that you can safely call wars. You really feel like a little ♥♥♥♥ amongst the total amount ♥♥♥♥ in the world. You are nothing, but as soon as you team up, you are able to at least do a difference. It will never be your name on the front pages, but it could be your faction's name.

The game can surely throw some players off at first. It is rude and harsh. You have to first get to know the game, enviroment and to control correctly before you are even ready to kill effectively. This can scare off a lot of people. I am still not totally fine the movement in the game. I feel a bit slow, cuffed.. I don't know, it just feels a bit wierd. It is something I have to learn, but it does not annoy me anymore.

You can be unlucky and join at a bad time, THIS IS IF YOU PLAY ON EU, where there are not that many online. This seems to cause a bit of bad behavior, and team killing seems more likely here. You will have trouble finding action, and what you find might be unbalanced as hell. I don't know how often this happens, but it does not seem to happen that much. I don't feel like weapons are unbalanced. They are more there for a prefered playstyle. An example would be that a sniper can have a high dmg weapon, but very slow firerate/reload. The other sniper has a quick shooting, but low damage sniper rifle. It forces two very different playstyles. So it is clearly not pay2win. I never even accused it of that, but I saw someone complaining about it. It is not.

I am not a fan of the classes easily outmatching other classes, but then I remembered this is not the purpose. You are never ment to go into a base as Light Infrantry and be the hero. This is teamwork. You have to be unfair, and burst in with more men, and smack the ones already laying down. That is just war.

My biggest issue now is the movement, which is something I just have to learn. Like everything in the world, when you first learned it, it becomes an easy task. I believe that good players have the movement under control a lot, which helps a lot to survive.

I had to change my opinion, this game is really good. If you have friends, and are able to teampeak, then this game would be amazing.


Pros:
Intense Action
Nice Loadout system/Class System
Teamwork is rewarding
Unique and Enormous battles
Tactical Warfare
A lot of different Vehicles
More Extreme Action
You can have air vehicles :O
Graphics are pretty neat

Cons:
Can at times be low population <- Yet if it is not, I don't really see any cons.
The world can feel a bit empty. There are zero flora or wildlife. <- I don't know how much you would pay attention, during a battle anyways, but it is always nice.
XP is a little slow, which often discourage unskilled players. <- It gives the feeling of no progress.
It is very hard to communicate and make plans for the fight.

reviewText:
Planetside 2: A Massively Multiplayer First Person Shooter
Planetside 2 is, not suprisingly, the original Planetside updated revamped and redesigned for the modern era of FPS gaming. Those of you who played the original may fondly remember getting ground to meat paste in the cavernous hallways of Tech plants, suppressing multiple entries with alien technology and driving around semi desolate continents with a rag tag gang of roughnecks in your back seat will be revitalised and disappointed by this next evolution of the series.

Planetside 2 does a lot right as far as a first person shooter is concerned. The gunplay is downright meaty and satisfying with plenty of metrics to feed back data on your performance in terms of accuracy, how many people you're killing and how often. While the game has its issues, such as patches occasionally introducing instability which is usually patched out quite quickly, it is overall an incredibly intense and wonderful experience to charge accross a battlefield towards a fortified enemy base with missiles, tank shells and dogfighting aircraft flying over your head.

The game offers a lot in terms of its gameplay, catering to the gung-ho get me to battle asap style where you quickly respawn and get into the fight blasting enemies away with your triple barrelled shotgun or your 200 bullet magazine miniature chaingun while also catering to a more squad and platoon oriented tactical style where rapid response forces to enemy attacks dropping 40+ players onto a base in unison to storm the control points like some elite special forces.

Each Empire in Planetside 2 share their similarities but also have massive contrasts in their theme, style and gameplay. There is a large pool of equipment available to all factions which are generally balanced and well rounded to the point where you could play without empire specific equipment on any of the factions and still have a large impact on the battle. The empire specific equipment reinforces the strong themes of each Faction, The Terran Republic are well rounded and sleek, favouring oppressive fire with rapid firing weaponry capable of suppressing an entire room with the Miniature chaingun. The New Conglomerate are bulky and favour raw power, their Jackhammer shotgun is capable of bursting someone down instantly provided you land all three shots in it's burst fire mode and beleive me thats no mean feat especially when there is an invisible bugger looking to make mincemeat of your kidneys from behind. The Vanu Sovereignty favour versatility and advanced technology with their Lasher assault rifle, a weapon capable of killing just as efficiently as any other with direct fire but also posessing the unique ability of being able to suppress doorways and enemy positions with its indirect fire splash damage. These weapons are just some examples of the awesome firepower that will be at your fingertips every time you log in. And thats just infantry play!

Each Faction also has thei own specific vehicles with their own strengths and weaknesses, such as the Prowler a terran tank with decidedly low armour but packing two main tank barrels and a high tuned engine makes it a capable fast attacking flank tank or utilizing its deploy seige mode a long range suppression platform capable of laying down massive firepower at the expense of mobility. The Vanguard, a Conglomerate tank is the frontline brawler, it comes equipped with a massive main cannon and a shield capable of blocking an absurd amount of damage for a few seconds which will get it through even the most hairy of engagements. The Magrider, a nimble hovertank that can't rotate it's main gun, but more than makes up for it by being able to strafe in and out of cover aswell as climb all but the most sheer of rockfaces allowing it to get into position to lay down some serious firepower on unsuspecting or unaware foes.

Honestly, theres way too much content to talk about efficiently in terms of the gameplay options available to players in Planetside 2, the best thing to do is try it out - its free, its fun, and it offers a different kind of gameplay for everyone. Whether you're a dedicated boots on the ground infantryman with your trusty anti tank rocket launcher or you have dreams of being an Ace in the sky with one of the empire dogfighting aircraft or even if you just want to play the support role, healing, repairing and ferrying allies from fight to fight. Planetside 2 has a lot to offer, give it a try! You might find yourself hooked!

The developers are also extremely active and work with the community often, by no means do I want to paint a perfect picture of this game - it is after all a massively multiplay online game, and as such things come with that territory such as occasional game, server and balance instability.

reviewText:
Still my favorite competitive shooter ever. This is all out war, seriously. The openess of the maps and the base setups create situations you will never experience in single map deathmatch games no matter how many people you pack in them. Lines of troops, tanks, airships punching through an enemy line and rushing the next base in a huge wave of chaos is something like I have never experienced before in a game. It really feels like sometimes I am on a Total War battlefield with how the action takes place on this grander scale. You can feel it when you and your friends are making a difference busting that choke point, and suddenly the tide turns and theres that rush of BOOM, MOVE OUT SOLDIERS!

As you get to know the maps and how the bases are tied together, you will understand this more. There is a particular area of a map where two bases can see each other with a vast stretch of open land between them. I have been part of tides trying to wave across this field to the next base with utter chaos all over, with gunfire flying from each base and tanks in there positions on either side, hundreds of troops battling out in between hiding behind rocks holding the line. AMAZING. In another area though you may have to fight your way up a hill, creating new situations and different strategies. The maps are varied and the areas have many ways to approach and take on a situation. You can go from these extremes down to going after that base thats available for the taking, but people are not looking at much, creating a smaller deathmatch like situation that can suddenly grow as people see the opening and push it.

This is truly a massive scale game when it comes to these crazy moments, but there is alot of depth to the classes and vehicles as well. Many upgrades and weapons to get, and alot can be done earning the in game certificates, the free to play model is done very well. Much like a good free to play, you will want to spend the money at some point, but you have plenty to do before, and do not feel forced into it. This game can be harsh, because due to its very chaotic and open nature, you will die ALOT. You as a single player will never dominate anything or anyone for a length of time, its the teamwork that counts here. To me in this game repairing a Sunderer is totally as good as a kill, because ANYTHING you can do to help your teamates will help you win that base. This makes support classes really stand out in this game, but all classes really have a place in the action, with each able to make special contributions to whats going on in the battlefield. The same goes for the vehicles, from the Sunderer mobile spawn point and nasty tanks, to troop dropping airships and fast agile dogfighters, this is a game not to be missed!

This game easily makes my top 10 list of games to play before you die.

10/10

reviewText:
So far, this is the closest game I have seen that actually resembles all-out war. Massive amounts of players, all attacking each other at the same time, each with different sides, strategies and weapons. Pretty good maps, as well.

The classes seem rather basic at first, but then there are all the different weapons, upgrades, abilities and strategies that can be used with each one. A (seemingly) very well thought out game. It also incorporates the social aspect of gaming, by allowing the creation of outfits, platoons and squads.

My only problems with it are the not-so-brilliant graphics, mainly the player models, and the fact that a great deal of in-game items require game currency that needs to be purchased for real money, or a lot of farming (can you farm PCs, or is it an NPC-specific thing?). The grahics are, compared to those of some games, pretty good, but aren't great, even on the highest graphics quality setting. Overall, however, it is a pretty good game with some good ideas

Rating:

Graphics: 6 / 10
Weaponry (Variation): 10 / 10
Weaponry (Realism): 9 / 10

reviewText:
Product received for free

Short version: Epic af and grindy af

Long version:
Pros:
1. You wanna be a fighter pilot? Be one and buy better upgrades in-game the better you get.
2. You wanna be a tanker? Be one and buy better upgrades in-game the better you get.
3. You wanna push the frontline along with other grunts? Be one and buy better upgrades in-game the better you get.
4. You wanna pilot a gunship and shoot everything? Be one and buy better upgrades in-game the better you get.
5. You wanna build a base with your buddies and make it your own personal outpost? Make one and buy better upgrades in-game the better you get.
6. You wanna feel extatic and epic? Solo capture facilities not at all-out war while taking care of reinforcements.
7. You wanna feel more extatic and epic? Go to the frontline where the main fight is. join the tens or hundreds of infantrymen and try making a difference.

Cons:
1. You wanna command a submarine or a huge warship? Yeah well you can't.
2. You wanna get high-end gear in a day? Yeah well you can't.
3. You wanna run it on an old laptop at 60fps? Yeah well you can't.

Summary:
The game is epic and there are moments where you will ragequit because everyone has a better framerate and performance than you, but there are also moments when you stand on a hill and look at the 100 infantrymen running and gunning across a desert or some other flatland while fighters fly above and often get shot down taking a few infantrymen with them when they hit the ground. The game is also very grindy. You need to get good in order to get more certification points so that you can get even better. It's a never-ending cycle. On the other hand the game is also extremely rewarding. Your first NS-44 Commissioner bought for 1000 certification points (without involving real money) makes you wanna brag considering the fact you wasted about 2-3k cert points earlier for upgrades you thought were needed. Lastly, Planetside 2 WILL crash and it WILL have poor performance unless you have a top-notch rig or settings down low.

reviewText:
My Review:

Action: This is as massive as it gets. There are few other games out there that have this many players involved in the same battle, especially FPS games. The map is huge which means that there could be 3-4 large battles going on at the same time. You can go into battle on foot, vehicles or by air. However, you will have to get into a transport of some sort to get to the action unless you want to run for a good 20 minutes. The developers ensured quick methods of getting to the action by using a pod that lands right into the battle, personel carriers that allow spawns, and smaller base spawns. Once you are there, the battles can be overwhelming. You could have 30 tanks on your side against 100 infantry, or it could be 20 planes against your tanks. Each battle offers something different. Points are required to spawn vehicles and planes, and this is something great because it balances things out. The most impressive feature is the realistic aiming/shooting. The further away your target, the longer it will take your bullets to get there. You have to shoot ahead of your target to actually hit it. This counts for sniper rifles too. Recoil and aim shake are also well done. The game requires just enough skill to make it demanding, but without losing the fun aspect.

5/5

Pay 2 Win: The game is free to play. However, people are able to buy weapons and skins for cash money. This is not a bad thing, they created a great game and need money. The only issue is that a lot of people do not like buying points or weapon packs. People would not mind buying the game after a free trial, but getting killed by some kids who bought all the best weapons makes me want to smash the screen. I am sure that a lot of players feel this way. In other words, the first 10 levels will be pretty rough. Once you get closer to 20, you should be racking up some nice points to buy upgrades for your guns and vehicles.

Setting: You are located on some random planets with some random tech centers. Yes, very creative... There are 3 sides, names that I don't remember. First side is human, second is human on roids, third is alien human on roids (I think). They all have masks on so I honestly don't know... To break it down: The humans use cold war era weapons such as flak cannons, rpgs, and revolvers. The alien looking dudes use plasma cannons. I chose humans. Rage on... Other than that, there is not much going on. One map is winter, one is desert themed, and the third is jungle/forest. Some cliffs, hills, valleys and that is pretty much it. In my opinion, they could have spiced up the maps with some random structures.

3/5

Graphics: This game will demand a good computer. Even if you have a decent desktop, you will still need to reduce the settings. We are talking about 2000 people on one map with battles that have 200+ people on. Bullets flying over your head. 40 tanks shooting plasma cannons in your face. This is all pretty intense and it requires a good PC. The main issue is that the game will not load even on powerful graphics cards. This is a terrible mistake by the developers. The settings are automatically raised to high and it stops you from loading the game. Reduce the settings in the game folder to medium and you should be good to go.

4/5

Overall: If you are looking for large scale fights, this is it. Look no further. Everything else is a joke. Playing alone will get boring, so invite friends. Shooting down your first aircraft with an rpg will make you cry crocodile tears of joy.

reviewText:
A multiplayer shooter that has amazing scope and satisfying gunplay has always kept Planetside 2 in my mind. I spent countless hours in beta and actually counted hours post release playing with friends and strangers alike. But however with all that time to play all I can really do is give you a warning.

This game is not friendly to the solo and casual. You will struggle to find battles alone. You will struggle to improve your character on a few hours of play alone. You will struggle to play this game the way it is intended outside of peak hours. The monetization of this game is thick, with expensive guns and aesthetic items that will constantly eat away at your psyche. Strangers will be many and many battles forgettable as you continue to fight in a war with no real consequence.

However: When you play this game with the way it is intended to be played. Large scale battles with hundreds of other players. Working with a small squad or a large platoon. You will have an absolute blast and I recommend every minute of it. But outside of prime time I really struggle to find something to do that I couldn't already do in the countless other smaller-scale, always available shooters like Battlefield, or Call of Duty, which will always have a nearly-full server waiting for you to join.

So find an outfit. Find a group of players that match your playstyle. Fight like hell.

reviewText:
Planetside 2, in it's current state, with the current development team, has no focus or incentive to play other than farming certs in which to unlock more weapons.

Battlerank is not a measure of skill, but of time spent in game. Squad and platoon level play is useless in the game with its current scale, as large outfits will redeploy quickly to hold off an attack, with no way to delay or intercept their reinforcements. Taking and holding a base is meaningless outside an alert, and the small number of continents and ease of redeploying means ultimately that fights only occur at the extreme ends of the scale. Either 'ghost capping' (no-one to fight) or 'zerging' (oh god my frame rate is 5fps, grenades and rockets aren't being rendered, and my shield aren't regenerating).

This could have been an amazing game, but i fear the community for it will be long dead before it will reach it's full potential
